These changes have made 20th-century industrial policy hopelessly out of date. Tax cuts or subsidies for research and development will not necessarily have job-creating spillover effects if firms intend to off-shore actual production while maintaining management and profits in the developed country.

Driven by the political and economic geography of global supply chains, the narrowness of the New Globalization is astounding. The titular convergence is the convergence of developing and developed world economies, but all relative growth in developing-world GDP and the vast majority of the billions of people lifted out of poverty in the 20th century came from just 11 developing nations that benefited directly or indirectly from the global supply chain revolution. The reason, according to Baldwin, is that the reduced cost of sharing ideas is a necessary, but not sufficient, condition for unbundling, which still requires strong property and contract rights, reliable and reasonably skilled labor, accessible transportation (for when in-person visits are required), and entree into a particular global supply chain, particularly those of manufacturing behemoths Germany, Japan, and the United States. As a result, particular patterns of integration emerged: Germany-Poland, the United States-Mexico, and Japan-Taiwan-China.

But Baldwins explanation for these colossal re-workings of the global economy fall short. He attributes almost the entire movement to the rise of information and communications technologies, lending everything an air of technological inevitability. The demise of American industry was just as inevitable in his telling as the emergence of global trade in the Age of Sail. The obvious alternatives are not considered. American manufacturing in China developed in the aftermath of the Chinese switching sides in the Cold War, and was part and parcel of an overarching and geopolitically aware development strategy. It was not technology that kept German and American companies out of Polish and Mexican towns only miles away, but the legal and political barriers.

A more radical narrative would look at the Great Convergence as the ultimate fruit of an atomistic, anti-nationalist vision for economic order. The postwar American project, in seeking to try to make the world safe for capitalism, faced two entangled challenges: to reduce barriers to trade, and to stave off working-class discontent. While at first export-oriented, it became clear by the 1980s that the combination was equally powerful in the other direction: reducing barriers to imports (driven by the GATT process) could place the working class into a vise between outsourcing and cost-reducing compromise. Labor recalcitrance could be punished by outsourcing, while outsourcing sent a message to American workers to get with the program and provided political cover for the pursuit of anti-labor policies for the sake of "competitiveness." The end of the Cold War spread this vision around the world with alarming speed, because it left the United States and its allies in substantial control of international investment, development aid, and the global financial system. Contra Baldwin, the developing world changing its tune on trade protectionism was not due to education or enlightenment, but the firm carrots and sticks of the Washington Consensus.

That doesn't mean that information technology doesn't play an important role in this process. Baldwin is correct that new communications links make a certain intensity of competition of coordination more viable (like outsourcing just-in-time parts deliveries or customer service phone calls). But it plays a role in appeasing the disenfranchised working class as well; hundreds of thousands of young men who can't find decently paid work are compensating with alluring entertainment and video games. But outsourcing wasn't the inevitable result of technological change, and encouraging the "onshoring" of American jobs isn't just about productivity and labor costs, but about creating a level playing field that compensates for foreign protectionism, subsidies, financial manipulation, shoddy regulation, and a tax structure that rewards shipping American jobs overseas.

Where Baldwin provides an accessible framing of contemporary economics, Zuboffs Age of Surveillance Capitalism aims to conceptualize and clarify a new mode of capitalism. Her book is well-timed, as in the wake of 2016, Big Tech companies are under fire from the Right by conservatives upset about perceived platform bias and from the Left by those of our credulous elites who believe that Russian trolls buying political Facebook ads represents a vital threat to our democracy.

Zuboffs fundamental idea is that a new form of capitalism is emerging based around a new form of surplus--the capturing, storing, processing, and reselling of information about human behavior. This "behavioral surplus" is akin to the labor surplus of classical Marxist analysis (the gap between the cost of capital and labor and what products can be sold for), except that the exchange occurs not only within the realm of economic activity but in and across every area of life, as human activity is increasingly mediated through the digital realm. Whereas Marx's alienation of labor separated and commoditized human creativity from the human creator and their conditions of life, surveillance capitalism's alienation of behavior creates and commoditizes a golem of human life that is controllable and predictable (able to be repurposed for marketing, financial predictions, etc.) quite apart from, and perhaps opposed to the interests of, the human beings whose data is being threshed to create these predictive models.

The phenomenology of this book is better than its political economy. Zuboff captures something of the experience of living with surveillance capitalism, of having one's experiences captured, reprocessed, and resold to you with the poking and prodding and nudging of cybernetic systems. Zuboffs book is overflowing with sociological insight on subjects ranging from how the 1960s led to a change in how digital capitalism is experienced (by fostering a demand for individualization) to the role of the 2000 dot-com bust in forcing Google's premature embrace of advertising. Steady insight and clever anecdotes, matched with Zuboffs crisp writing, help maintain the reader's interest far longer than most inches-thick doorstoppers with "capital" in the title. But Zuboff seems enamored of the supposed "unprecedentedness" of her argument. She describes modern data scientists as the descendants of behavioral scientist B.F. Skinner but fails to contend with the classic critique of behavioralism: that it simply doesn't work. Nowhere in her 30-page index will one find mention of cybernetics, the postwar scientific discipline that gave rise to modern artificial intelligence research and had many of the same utopian aspirations as todays tech prophets, and faced many of the same critiques.

Zuboff constructs a new vocabulary to describe and elaborate her notions of "behavioral surplus" and the new institutional forms and practices it is leading to. At times, this comes across as tautological and hysterical. Zuboff seems to take for granted that Google displaying a search ad for Starbucks in the morning when one might be in want of a caffeinated buzz is a sinister "intervention] in our experience to shape our behavior in ways that favor surveillance capitalists commercial outcomes," with new "automated protocols designed to influence and modify human behavior at scale as the means of production is subordinated to a new and more complex means of behavioral modification." Could not one describe a Coca-Cola radio ad playing on a hot summers day the same way? As thinkers like Adorno understood generations ago, molding and hijacking desire is an essential aspect of modern capitalism. The surveillance capitalism might be using powerful new means, but it is hardly the "mutation" from some other hypothetical, more humanistic version of capitalism that Zuboff says it is.

This is a book to be wrestled with, and others are (Evgeny Morozov's biting 17,000-word review feels as long as the book). But no one has yet addressed what I believe to be the most telling problem with the book: that Zuboff is simply wrong about how companies like Google and Facebook make money. Zuboff asserts that, following Google's construction of a rudimentary ad personalization system, "henceforth, revenues and growth would depend upon more behavioral surplus." This is, in fact, the central claim of the book: that a new form of capitalism that depends upon the capture and exploitation of behavioral surplus is emerging. But she provides zero evidence for this claim and, for a business school professor, seems uninterested in analyzing Google and Facebooks sources of profit. She interviews data scientists and innovators, but no MBAs, accountants, or lawyers.

Facebook and Google make money when users click on ads. Surveillancebased personalization increases the click-through-rate (the percentage of ads shown that are clicked on) from the low single digits... to the slightly higher single digits. The most important surveillancebased marginal improvements in ad performance are the most trivial. If you submit a Google search for an appliance part or visit an online shop, you'll see ads for dryer motors and such for a little while. You can find them with about the same accuracy as TV-demographic or periodical advertisements. Google and Facebook have actually made high-quality, targeted advertising much more accessible to small businesses--large corporations have always benefited from the kinds of "behavioral modification" Zuboff is worried about. A minuscule fraction of these ads, of course, are actually clicked on: about 2 percent for search ads (where you are actively looking for the thing being advertised) and a whopping 0.3 percent for display ads on websites. If Google gave up all of the "surveillance" behaviors Zuboff identified and limited themselves to personalizing ads based on search terms alone, the quality of ads would decline only marginally. The volume of clicked-on ads, and the prices advertisers are willing to pay for them, determine revenues.

If Google's profits do not, in fact, rely on "behavioral surplus," where do they come from? Whence sustainable profits in capitalism always come: monopoly. Even as internet usage has exploded worldwide, Google maintains 92 percent of all search market share. But search is only a small portion of Google's overall ad sales. The fundamental currency of the internet is not surveillance or data but attention. As internet video was first becoming feasible, Google bought YouTube. As display and banner ads sales on websites became automated, Google acquired Doubleclick, the market leader in web advertising. Google's profits emerge not because they are so good at personalizing ads to you, but because almost every ad you see on the internet is actually a Google ad.

Peter Thiel has Google's number. In a remarkable exchange with then-Google CEO Eric Schmidt, Thiel pointed to Google's then-$50 billion pile of cash as evidence that Google is no longer a technology company, but a monopolist (protected by intellectual property, network effects, and the ability to acquire or destroy any real competitors). Within Zuboff's framework, Google should be making capital investments to acquire ever more data. It generally isn't doing that; its biggest investments are in machine learning, data centers, cloud infrastructure, real estate, and acquisitions. It is heavily focused on competing for market share in enterprise cloud computing services (through Google Cloud) and maintaining market share for the future of advertising--mobile and voice computing. Within the logic of financial capitalism, the share value of a company depends on persuasive narratives of future profit, usually tied to how financial analysts see the growth trajectory of different sectors and business models over time.

So even if all of Google's profits are now and will for the foreseeable future emerge from network position and monopolistic control of huge swathes of internet architecture, the company cannot ever admit that, because it would indicate the company's future revenue growth had slowed and that it was vulnerable to antitrust action. It must therefore maintain what Thiel called "the ministry of propaganda"--"moonshot" high technology efforts like flying cars and quantum computing to achieve profitable breakthroughs. They seem straight out of science fiction because they are science fiction.

The profits and share prices of big technology companies also benefit from two specific legal strategies. The first is that they are businesses suspiciously well-tailored to avoid the enforcement of antitrust action, especially in the United States, where radically laissez-faire theories have made cost to the consumer essentially the only criterion (free service, no cost to consumers). More importantly, the ephemerality of internet companies makes it easy to book profits wherever one wishes. American businesses can sell ads to American consumers on American servers run by American engineers, but Google can book the profits in Ireland by claiming that its profits come from its intellectual property held there.

When Zuboff is writing on Silicon Valley's utopian aspirations, subtle new forms of manipulation and control, and how surveillance and information systems are being used to shape our minds and desires, she is compelling. But despite writing a book about capitalism, Zuboff has failed to follow the money. No doubt companies like Google and Facebook represent a new development in the history of capitalism. But that is due to as much to the combination of rapid scalability, monopoly, and effect on human consciousness as to surveillance or data accumulation. She has identified a real new struggle for power and profit, but one whose greatest impacts are yet to come.

An overemphasis on the exotic blinds Zuboff to the quotidian manipulations of attention, market power, and profit that are actually driving our new Gilded Age. And a focus on for-profit surveillance leads to almost no grappling with the role the state will play. The province of control and discipline has always been far more the interest of the state, and the greatest innovator of surveillance power is the Communist Party of China. Zuboff assumes that surveillance and data-based control systems in the West will be market-led; advanced surveillance systems coming home from the War on Terror should make us question this conclusion.

Perhaps a far more troubling problem for Zuboff s model is that it excludes precisely the kinds of behavioral modification that ought to worry us. For Zuboff, the concern is the gap between personalization aimed at the user's interests and personalized targeting for the surveillance capitalist's profit (again, advertising). And yet, targeted, paid advertisements make up an infinitesimal fraction of how users experience platforms like Facebook and Google. All the evidence suggests that the organic behavior of users, and the ways it is amplified and channeled as personalized content to other users for the purposes of maximizing engagement, is the real challenge of these platforms for their content, and one that corporations are truly at a loss as to how to counter. What James Poulos calls the techno-gnostic empire of memory, hyper-individuation, and behavioral control is going to be way bigger, weirder, and more coercive than Google.

Baldwin claims his titular Great Convergence is the inevitable result of technological imperatives. Zuboff offers some minor tinkers to restrain the surveillance parts of surveillance capitalism, but still clings to the vision of capitalism restored to "serve our genuine interests" as consumers. Neither reckons with the philosophical and historical roots of the present populism. The outsourcing of American jobs was not the product of technological inevitability, but geopolitical shifts and a bipartisan elite assault on American workers. The new Gilded Age is not the product of "the capture of behavioral surplus" (real challenges though it raises), but of the exploitation of the American legal and political system to lock in extravagant shareholder returns on the backs of the American taxpayer. While these books have much to offer, do not accept their counsels of despair. The American people may yet assert the primacy of politics over economics, of self-government over artificial and usurious profit, and restrain the financial and corporate order built upon their backs.

by JONATHAN ASKONAS

Jonathan Askonas is an assistant professor of politics at the Catholic University of America and fellow at the Center for the Study of Statesmanship.

urn:contentItem:5V6M-JSG1-JBG3-61M7-00000-00Markets Applaud China's Economic Plan2019-01-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:08:49ZLexisNexisSection BColumn 0Business/Financial DeskPg. 2Markets Applaud China's Economic PlanBy THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

Stocks in the United States rallied to their highest level in more than a month on Tuesday after China's government moved to inject more life into its economy by cutting taxes and increasing spending. Netflixled a surge in high-tech companies.

Health care companies and banks rose as major companies including UnitedHealth and JPMorgan Chaseannounced their fourth-quarter results.

The British pound wobbled after legislators soundly rejected Prime Minister Theresa May's plan governing her country's departure from the European Union. While the deal's defeat might herald more chaos for companies in Britain and Europe in the months ahead, the outcome of the vote was long expected and stocks didn't react much.

The S&P 500-stock index rose 27.69 points, or 1.1 percent, to 2,610.30, its first close above 2,600 since Dec. 13. The Dow Jones industrial average added 155.75 points, or 0.7 percent, to 24,065.59.

The Nasdaq jumped 117.92 points, or 1.7 percent, to 7,023.83.

Chinese leaders plan to reduce taxes, increase government spending, and provide financing to private and small enterprises in a bid to strengthen the world's second-largest economy. China is enduring its worst slowdown since the global financial crisis, partly because of a punishing tariff dispute with the United States.

That helped technology companies, which make big chunks of their sales in China. Microsoft rose 2.9 percent to $105.01, and Broadcom climbed 2.2 percent to $256.49.

Netflixclimbed 6.5 percent to $354.75 as it announced the biggest price increase in its history to help pay for its huge investment in original shows and films and finance the heavy debt it has assumed to ward off rivals such as Amazon, Disney and AT&T.

That touched off strong gains for other big tech stocks: Facebook rose 2.4 percent to $148.95, Amazon gained 3.5 percent to $1,674.56, and Google's parent company, Alphabet, jumped 3.3 percent to $1,086.51.

Netflixhas jumped 32.5 percent in 2019 but was worth almost $420 a share in July.

Delta Air Lines became one of the first companies to detail how the partial shutdown of the federal government is affecting its business. The airline says it's on pace to lose $25 million in revenue this month. Its chief executive, Ed Bastian, said the shutdown is keeping Delta from using new Airbus jets because the planes must be certified by safety regulators. They have been furloughed since Dec. 22.

An unusually high number of airport screeners have been missing work after they did not get paychecks last week, contributing to long lines at some airports.

Delta met Wall Street's expectations in the fourth quarter. Its stock gyrated and finished with a gain of 0.2 percent at $47.83.

The paint maker Sherwin-Williams said it was ''disappointed'' with its sales in October and November, and its profit and sales in the fourth quarter fell short of Wall Street's estimates. Its stock fell 4.1 percent to $381.44. The home improvement retailer Home Depot gave up 1.3 percent to $176.47 while Lowe's slid 2.1 percent to $94.91.

Oil prices rose as investors felt a bit better about China's economic growth. Benchmark United States crude added 3.2 percent to $52.11 a barrel in New York. The international standard, Brent crude, gained 2.8 percent to $60.64 a barrel in London.

Wholesale gasoline jumped 3.5 percent to $1.41 a gallon. Heating oil rose 1.1 percent to $1.87 a gallon, and natural gas fell 2.5 percent to $3.50 per 1,000 cubic feet.

Gold slipped 0.2 percent to $1,286.20 an ounce, and silver fell 0.4 percent to $15.62 an ounce. Copper was unchanged at $2.63 a pound.

Bond prices inched lower. The yield on the 10-year Treasury note rose to 2.72 percent from 2.71 percent.

The dollar rose to 108.57 yen from 108.20 yen. The euro dipped to $1.1402 from $1.1465.

This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

CHARTS: The S&P 500 Index: Position of the S&P 500 index at 1-minute intervals on Tuesday. (Source: Refinitiv)

Producer Prices: Index of finished goods prices and services, 2009 =100, seasonally adjusted. (Source: Labor Department)

urn:contentItem:5WMN-SJT1-DXH2-62D9-00000-00Markets Awaiting Rate Call; Report: Tech Executives Invited to White House Today, Huawei Ban Expected to Come Up; Puerto Rico Prepares for Protests to Force Governor to Resign; Bank Of America CEO Brian Moynihan On Ongoing Debt Ceiling Negotiations; Massive Heat Wave Blamed For, At Least Six Deaths; Great White Shark Jumps At Fishing Boat; CBS Versus DirecTV; California Google San Jose Plans; Deepfake And A.I. Cyber Attacks2019-07-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:08:49ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA6:00 AM ESTMichael Block, Mitch Roschelle, Lee Carter, Michael LeeNEWSFinancial072201cb.231Markets Awaiting Rate Call; Report: Tech Executives Invited to White House Today, Huawei Ban Expected to Come Up; Puerto Rico Prepares for Protests to Force Governor to Resign; Bank Of America CEO Brian Moynihan On Ongoing Debt Ceiling Negotiations; Massive Heat Wave Blamed For, At Least Six Deaths; Great White Shark Jumps At Fishing Boat; CBS Versus DirecTV; California Google San Jose Plans; Deepfake And A.I. Cyber AttacksDagen McDowell, Cheryl Casone, Maria Bartiromo, Deirdre Bolton; Brett Larson

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good to see both of you, fantastic ladies, Cheryl Casone and Deirdre Bolton. Good morning, everyone. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo, it is Monday, July 22nd, your top stories at 6:00 a.m. Eastern. Another big week of earnings, this time, we've got big tech names, including Facebook, Twitter, Google's parent, Alphabet, all reporting. This morning, the focus is on Halliburton. We have the numbers coming up.

Futures reporting to a higher open this morning, growing tensions with Iran, Prime Minister Theresa May holding an emergency meeting following the seizure of a U.K. tanker by Iran's Revolutionary Guard, this latest incident sending oil prices higher, and the Lion King roaring at the box office, but it's not the only Disney film breaking records this weekend, details straight ahead.

MORNINGS WITH MARIA starts right now.

We have a big show coming up this morning. Maria's exclusive interview is on deck with Bank of America chairman and CEO, Brian Moynihan. They talk about everything from the debt ceiling to trade and more, you don't want to miss it.

And joining the conversation this morning, pollster and Maslansky & Partners president, Lee Carter, PWC partner, Mitch Roschelle and market strategist at Third Seven Advisors, Michael Block, much to discuss, Mike already says that he has something outrageous to say on China trade, so hold that thought. We're going get to it shortly. OK.

Futures are pointing to a higher open this morning, we have gains across the board, a 52-point gain on the Dow Futures. Investors, of course, are waiting for the busiest week of the earning season. Last week, losing week for the markets, a real whiplash about whether the Federal Reserve is going to cut a quarter of a point, half a point?

Again, it seems like the markets are trading all on monetary policy, but what about earnings? Ten of the 30, so one-third of the Dow components, more than one quarter of the S&P 500 report this week, and the big names to watch, Facebook and Tesla, coming out on Wednesday, Google's parent, Alphabet and Amazon, on Thursday. Mike Block, what are you expecting?

MICHAEL BLOCK, MARKET STRATEGIST, THIRD SEVEN ADVISORS: We have some big names reporting this week. And, you know, for much of this year, I've been saying that it's all about growth. Well, this is some of these big companies chance to show that. Can Facebook and Amazon and Alphabet really answer some of the concerns?

Last week, we saw Netflix blow up because their non-U.S. ads weren't good. But we also saw Microsoft excel on the cloud. What's it going to be for Amazon? Are they going to show the growth in retail sales? Is this going to be about the cloud?

Can Alphabet recover from what was a bad quarter, last quarter? Can they continue to be the leadership here? And would that be enough for the overall market? Is it a good thing when only four stocks are -- amount for all the gains in the S&P 500?

MCDOWELL: Right. So to your --

BLOCK: Yes.

MCDOWELL: -- point, this is the front page story in the Wall Street Journal, this is above the full story, I'll hold it up, it's right there, because I'm a nerd, I still have newspapers. So, it's Microsoft, Apple, Amazon and Facebook accounted for 19 percent of the S&P 500's total return this year, and I think it's the best performance, so far, in 2019, the biggest gain since '98, so a little bubbly.

MITCH ROSCHELLE, PARTNER, PWC: What's interesting is, when all of the noise out there, geopolitically, China trade, and concerns about global economic growth. Those are the companies that investors are, sort of, flocking to.

What's interesting is the treasury is the flight to safety asset class, as are those big FANG names. And it's interesting how the market's transformed from being 500 stocks to 4 that people run to when they're worried about what's going on around the world.

MCDOWELL: And we talked about the Fed, I mentioned briefly the Federal Reserve decision and, kind of, a whiplash in the markets last week. What was it, it was Williams from the New York Fed on Thursday.

BLOCK: Williams getting all academic on us and talking about a half percent neutral rate and freaking everyone out. He's an academic. He's been doing this his entire career. This is what he does.

MCDOWELL: And then they had to send out the balloon through the Wall Street Journal on Friday, saying wait a minute, wait a minute, wait a minute, right? It's only going to be a quarter of a point.

BLOCK: It's a bit of comedy. We're going to see where it'll go. By the way, I want to point out, we've talked about the FANG stocks in the past, you look at Facebook, Apple, Microsoft, Amazon now, that spells F.A.M.A, which for us finance geeks is really funny because Eugene Fama is the guy who told us to buy small cap value stock opposed to large cap growth stock.

MCDOWELL: It was Fama and French.

BLOCK: Yes, it was Fama and French.

MCDOWELL: It was Fama and French.

BLOCK: Sorry French, didn't mean to leave you out.

MCDOWELL: We want to get -- let's talk about economic numbers ahead of the Federal Reserve decision next week. So, we get the first reading on second quarter growth out on Friday, ahead of the Central Bank's decision next week.

And again, we were talking about interest rate cuts, but in terms what's coming out this week. Also, we get new home sales numbers and also durable goods which are scheduled on Thursday and then second quarter. So, what about second quarter growth, what are we expecting at that 3.1 percent growth in the first quarter?

ROSCHELLE: GDP now, the Atlanta Fed has it at 1.6, which they sometimes have been wildly inaccurate, but I have a good feeling about second quarter, because if you look at the earnings, the banks all talked about how the consumer was really, really strong and drove their business.

If you look at the retail sales number that came out last week, that number was strong. I think the consumers are driving this economy and the consumers fairly confident. So I'm fairly optimistic about second quarter GDP, I think it's going to be higher than that.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY & PARTNERS: I'm really interested to see what's going to happen with real estate, though, because it seems like that's a different, you know, that's -- we've got so many great numbers and consumer confidence, and we're seeing real estate's not doing as well. So, I'm curious to see how that's all going to play out.

MCDOWELL: How's confidence holding up in this new environment, because again, I had this moment, and we're going to talk about the continued fight with the squad between President Trump and these four young congresswomen, but I'm driving around throughout the south and the roads are just wall-to- wall traffic, it's bumper-to-bumper traffic.

People are out, they're spending, and I thought, you know what, I wonder how many of these people who are out enjoying like the lowest unemployment rate that we've had in nearly half a century.

And these incredible wage gains, people are out, they're driving, they're enjoying their summer despite a hundred degree temperatures, they're not paying attention to that. Now, I wonder how confidence is reacting to just the feel good vibes about the economy, regardless of what's coming out of Washington.

CARTER: Consumer confidence set an all-time high, I mean, when you look at, I mean, I'm not sure it's all-time high, but it certainly continues to increase, and despite the fact that people are saying there's a recession coming, that these numbers are inflated, that we're in a bubble, all these kinds of things that you hear over and over again, that's not what the consumer is saying.

They're out there spending, they're feeling good. People are feeling better about the economy than they have, and when you look at the numbers in 2012, where we are today, it's unbelievable how much better people are feeling about where we are as a country and about our future.

ROSCHELLE: Despite the fact that some of the candidates on the Democratic side of the campaign trail are trying to talk this country into a recession.

CARTER: Well, that, I think, is one the most fascinating things, it's almost like they're trying to talk us out of feeling good. So, I -- if you look at some of the messaging Elizabeth Warren and others are doing, it's economic growth, it's not working for every man, it's working -- that's what they're trying to say. They're saying, is it working for you, it's working for the wealthy, and it's working for companies.

But when you -- when you survey people and you talk to people out there, that's not how they feel. They're feeling like this is the best economy that we've ever had. And, you know --

MCDOWELL: And nonsupervisory wages have been growing faster than the wages of managers. That lower-skilled individuals in this country, their wages are growing faster than people, in some instances, that have college degrees or higher.

So, again, you have to be very careful when you tell somebody, you don't really feel as good as you think you do. It doesn't -- you feel -- they could come across like they're not telling the truth to people.

CARTER: That's right. And I think that the thing that they need to understand is there's a difference -- and you say this all the time, Dagen, you say it's the policies versus the politics, and I think that people don't like the politics, they're not optimistic about the tone and the tenor of our environment right now, but they feel very good about the economics and their pocket books.

MCDOWELL: And I do want to point out because the president was still tweeting about these four female lawmakers, saying that he doesn't think -- he said this yesterday morning, I think it was about 8:00 in the morning, that he doesn't think they are capable of loving our country, so this continues.

I'm going to talk to you later in the show about what's the method to this madness here. So --

CARTER: There is one.

MCDOWELL: There is one. Because, again, people would come up to me and ask me to explain what was going on, like, you know, not today. So, well, this is on deck this week, in Washington Wednesday, former Special Counsel Robert Mueller testifying before the House Judiciary and Intelligence Committees.

Maria Bartiromo sat down with ranking Judiciary Committee member, Georgia congressman, Doug Collins, about what he plans to ask Mueller, so listen to this. I'll get everybody's reaction.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Are you going to be asking specifically if he looked at the origin of that investigation, why they started to investigate Donald Trump in the first place?

REP. DOUG COLLINS (R-GA): We've got some great guys on our side and gals that are going to ask him really pointed questions to make sure that the American people understand this is not a vacuum that the Democrats have completely, to say the president was doing something wrong.

We're going to also go back to that corrupt kabal and others, I think, as you look at it in general that need to be part of this picture. Remember, the Mueller report is a one-sided report that is not been questioned from the other side. This is our chance to do that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Lee, what are you expecting?

CARTER: What? I'm expecting a mess. You know, I also wonder a lot of times, this is going to be to do about nothing, we're anticipating so much. I think that we're going to hear a lot more from the sidelines that we're actually going to see when you actually get down to it.

MCDOWELL: Does the market care? Do investors --

ROSCHELLE: I was about to say that, I don't think the market cares and what's interesting is, so much time has passed since this dust-up last time. I think re-dusting it up -- not only the market, but I think voters are just going to say --

CARTER: I think people already made up their minds.

MCDOWELL: So you had -- so we're saving this to the end. You have some bomb you're going to land about the China trade, tell us, before we go to break.

BLOCK: Yes, I'll say --

MCDOWELL: Hit me.

BLOCK: I'll say this really quickly, what's going on here is this -- fact of the matter is, and we can agree with him and disagree, the point thing, this is how he feels. President Xi over in China does not trust Donald Trump full stop. That's what it comes down to -- he looks at the Iran deal and we can all say that was a terrible deal, of course, President Trump did away with it.

The Chinese look at this and they're saying, he breaks deals, we can't make a deal with him, and that's kind of the mindset now. They're actually of the mindset of, let's wait this out until next year, let's see if he loses the election, we're in no hurry to do this because we don't trust him. We don't trust any deal we make with him.

All of us can disagree with that reason. The important thing is, that's what's really happening in China. I'm not --

MCDOWELL: But we don't --

MCDOWELL: But we went into this, not trusting the Chinese because of the theft of intellectual property --

BLOCK: Sure.

MCDOWELL: -- and the forced surrender of technology. And again, using Huawei to essentially -- as a trap door to spy on the world, the United States and other nations, so --

BLOCK: All of that is irrelevant. The thing that I'm saying is --

MCDOWELL: No, it's not -- it's not irrelevant.

BLOCK: No, it is relevant. It is relevant.

MCDOWELL: Yes, it's relevant not irrelevant, but go ahead.

BLOCK: What I'm trying -- what I'm trying to say here is this, there's this thought that both sides are going to play nice, shake hands and make some, sort of, deal that's going to make markets go higher, whether it works or not, remains to be seen.

But I'm telling you that the actual mindset going on in China, right now, from what I'm getting from some high-placed people, is that they just don't even want to make a deal.

MCDOWELL: But if nothing changes in terms of where we are right now, Mitch, that's not necessarily bad for the market. I think that you have a market. You have investors and corporate executives. They are grappling with the existing tariffs that we have on Chinese goods. So, a status quo from here, until even after the election would be OK for the economy and the markets.

ROSCHELLE: Most likely. And I think as time goes on, corporate managers are less and less convinced that anything is going to happen and they're just moving forward.

MCDOWELL: And moving production too.

ROSCHELLE: Vietnam and India.

BLOCK: There's a lot going on. You know, one thing that's also going on overnight was, Japan and South Korea are having their own trade dispute, and Samsung might be moving more production here to the U.S. They already have a big chip facility in Austin, Texas and maybe moving more. There are so many moving parts here.

And yes, there could be a lot of adaptation if there's no deal and no progress. Let's see how it works out. My point is, there is this expectation, oh, they'll get a deal done once the summer is over. I'm not seeing it.

MCDOWELL: OK.

ROSCHELLE: Traffic gets worse --

MCDOWELL: How about ratifying that -- the new NAFTA?

BLOCK: Oh sure.

MCDOWELL: We'll take that USMCA.

BLOCK: Yes, let's get through that. Let's get some infrastructure --

MCDOWELL: Open the desk drawer. Open the desk drawer, take it out, and move it to the floor.

BLOCK: No. We're too busy fighting with each other.

MCDOWELL: Yes, exactly, and tweeting, fact on a tear. Major technology companies powering the markets recent gains, what it means for earning season, straight ahead. Plus, the Lion King roars at the box office, Disney's remake of its classic stories stampeding into theaters, the roundup, next.

MCDOWELL: A massive protest expected in Puerto Rico today, as the governor refuses to resign, Cheryl Casone has more details, hey, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hey, Dagen, good morning. Hundreds of thousands of people are expected to take over one of the island's busiest roads today. They're hoping to convince Governor Ricardo Rossello to step down.

Overnight, Rossello announced he will not seek re-election, but he also won't quit over a leaked online conversation, showing him mocking women and hurricane victims. Today will mark the 10th straight day of protest there.

Well, Equifax could pay around $700 million to settle with the Federal Trade Commission over at 2017 data breach. Wall Street journal is reporting that the deal would resolve investigations by the FTC, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau and most states. It would also resolve a nationwide consumer class action lawsuit, the breach, one of the largest affecting private information.

And Disney's Lion King devoured the competition at the weekend box office.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JAMES EARL JONES, VOICE OF MUFASA, THE LION KING: You must take your place in the Circle of Life.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: The remake grossed $185 million in the U.S., roaring passed expectations. I'm trying, it's Monday. It's already earned more than half a billion dollars worldwide. And then, here's some news, the Avengers: End Game which didn't make the top 10, doesn't even matter at this point.

With 1.5 million globally added, over this past weekend, it now has finally surpassed Avatar's all-time record, reaching $2.79 billion, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: That's incredible.

CASONE: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much, Cheryl. Who went to see it? Do you have a young daughter?

BLOCK: We watched Toy Story 4 yesterday.

MCDOWELL: Oh, was it awesome?

BLOCK: Also Disney Pixar, fantastic, yes. That's my first Toy Story movie. I never saw any of them.

MCDOWELL: I'll take James Earl Joyce's -- James Earl Jones. Joyce is my mother's name that's why I said that, James Earl Jones' voice, over Tom Hanks, though, any day.

BLOCK: Oh, sure.

MCDOWELL: Just saying.

BLOCK: Yes.

ROSCHELLE: Buzz or Woody? I'm a -- I'm a Woody guy. I don't know. Sorry audience. I just --

BLOCK: If you see the new one, Forky.

ROSCHELLE: Oh, really? There's a new character?

BLOCK: There's a new character named Forky. It's very clever.

MCDOWELL: OK. We'll leave it at that.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: I don't know. I never quite understood the need to make -- remake the Lion King, but I think that that speaks volumes about the need for that.

BLOCK: For the -- for the record, I was laughing hard with my daughter.

MCDOWELL: Yes, exactly. All right, major earnings on tap, 10 Dow components reporting this week ahead of the Fed possibly cutting interest rates, how the market is reacting.

And July heat wave, millions of Americans sweated out this weekend, dealing with blistering temperatures, but there is finally some relief in sight, and a surprise for a lifetime, for one family, when an uninvited guest yes, gets in the middle of their day of fishing, more ahead.

MCDOWELL: Future pointing the gains across the board, a 58-point-gain on the Dow Futures after a losing week for the markets last week. But will earnings turn it all around? We have mega earnings on tap, economic numbers out and then a possible rate cut.

Joining me now, Altium Wealth portfolio manager, market strategist, Mike Lee, again, I still think it's about the Fed and what the Federal Reserve is going to do. You saw what markets did last week. It's like, quarter of like half a point, yes. Oh, it's only a quarter of a point. What about earnings here?

MICHAEL LEE, PORTFOLIO MANAGER AND MARKET STRATEGIST, ALTIUM WEALTH: You know, I'd say expectations of this quarter are super low. We're looking at -- right now, it's down 1.8, 1.9 percent, and revenue up just under 4 percent, so big misses, big beats, you know, those -- they'll get rewarded and, you know, taken down, respectively, but everything is about the Fed right now.

Are we going to get a rate cut? I personally think we're at 25-basis points. I'm 100 percent sure about that 25-basis point. At this next meeting, I think the Fed could throw us for a little bit of a curve ball and then reward us later, because the market is just ahead of their ski tips here, thinking that we're going to get 50 or 75 basis points in this meeting or by the end of the year, is insane.

Over the last few weeks, let's look some of the data that we got, we got a blowout jobs number, we've got the New York Fed -- you know, Empire State manufacturing blowing away estimates, the Philly Fed coming in like four times estimates.

Retail sales beating, inflation data coming in higher. There's no reason to cut rates now, other than to stop the dollar from appreciating, substantially, against the rest of the world.

MCDOWELL: Mike?

BLOCK: Yes, just one thought, you know, I'm actually still bullish on the dollar, rate cut or not. You know, the ECB is still cutting. You know, there are other factors that are going to take the dollar down. It's just a matter of its run so far ahead that it's going to come in.

LEE: Yes. Well -- I agree with your thesis that the dollars are going to continue to get stronger, and I think what a lot of that has to do, is the tax cut and regulatory reform that we've seen here. The U.S. is now a much more tractive investment than it was just a few years ago, because it's much easier to do business.

And what's happening is, a lot of growth for the rest the world is getting sucked back to America. So, as long as we are the best game in town, and that gap continues to widen, I don't see how the dollar cannot continue to get stronger, and the Fed is not going to zero.

ROSCHELLE: But if dollar continues to get strong, that continues to weigh on corporate earnings with, you know, a half of the revenue of the S&P 500 earned abroad, right?

LEE: Yes. So -- yes, and I think that's largely baked into expectations, it makes it more difficult to say, you know, to manufacture and, kind of, remake rework the base here, but the flipside of that, is a lot of these tech companies, right, that are continuing to be growing and growing and growing, like, that's going to be dollar irrelevant.

And that I think markets can go much, much higher here, because we're at 17 times forward earnings. The economy -- like you were just saying about, I think, GDP estimates, a little bit too low for this quarter as it were for the first quarter, and then things could continue to pick up for the next half of this year, through the rest of this year, into next year.

MCDOWELL: Even if the Fed don't deliver, even if the Fed don't deliver. You think that markets will clearly be disappointed if the Fed doesn't cut next week.

LEE: You know, if the Fed -- I think you're going to continue to get this accommodative language, it may be too aggress over the last few weeks, which is why they came out, so expect to get something here, either by the way of transparency into the next rate cut, or a rate cut right here.

But I think we're one and done. It's very hard to rationalize with this strong of an economy that you're cutting rates.

ROSCHELLE: One of the things, Mike, you mentioned maybe three, four months ago on this show, was you thought the market was trying to bully the Fed by their behavior in the fourth quarter last year, to say you've got to be more accommodative, so if they don't get the cut that they're looking for, how do you think markets are going to react? They're going to start bulling the Fed again?

LEE: Yes, I think you'd get a selloff, and for investors out there, sitting with cash, you know, that is your opportunity to come in. So, I think at this next meeting, no matter what we get, you're most likely going to get a selloff because let's just say, hypothetically, if we get 75 basis points, which I don't think we are, the market will sell off because they're going to say, hey --

ROSCHELLE: They can sell the news.

LEE: What are they going to say? Hey, what does the Fed know that we don't?

ROSCHELLE: Right.

LEE: If you get 50 basis points, that's, kind of, in line with expectation, so that's sell the news, we get 25 basis points, well, that's a huge disappointment. So, I think this is a sell-the-news type trading event for an entry point. But for those of us that are sitting in this, and this for a long run, like, just ride just through us. This business cycle is going to continue going, and going, and going, right?

You really -- you don't have a ton of leverage in this economy. A little bit in the S&P 500, we're getting a little bit elevated there, but on the consumer side, if you look at debt service as a percentage of take home income, it's at the lowest level in 30 years.

You look at consumer confidence, consumer comfort, consumer sentiment, all the near the highest levels ever, 1.3 million more jobs available, people looking for work. It's really an unbelievable shape right now.

BLOCK: I just want to point out that the dollar does stay stronger, what sectors benefit, one of them is U.S. retail. U.S. consumer has more purchasing power, everything else help constant.

MCDOWELL: You left out in terms of investors pushing Fed to cut rates, and who use the word, bullying? We left out how the president might react to a dollar that continues to be strong and a Fed that doesn't cut rates aggressively. I'll just leave it at that.

LEE: He's a little bit of a victim of his own success here, but it's -- you know, afraid (INAUDIBLE) follow zero hedge. You know, it's -- the Fed shouldn't make policy based on the price of the S&P 500, but it seems like that plays a much greater role than it should in this day and age.

BLOCK: The market dependent, full step.

MCDOWELL: Yes, Mike, good to see you.

LEE: Thanks for having me.

MCDOWELL: Michael Lee from Altium. Coming up, Maria's exclusive sit down with Bank of America CEO Brian Moynihan, covering topics from the debt ceiling to trade negotiations, plus a real-life jaws moment caught on camera.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Good one.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Oh, my God!

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: A great white shark drops in on a family fishing trip, more ahead.

MCDOWELL: Welcome back. I'm Dagen McDowell, in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, July 22nd. Your top stories at 6:30 a.m. Eastern.

Futures are showing gains across the board. 57 point gain on the Dow Futures. The Dow, Nasdaq, and S&P winning the -- ending week down, for the first time in three weeks. And see the losses there.

Looking for a rebound this morning. What's happening in Europe at the moment? We have slight gains across the board in England, France, and Germany. In Asia overnight, it was red across the board for all the major markets there as expectations were a deep interest rate cut by fed e here in the U.S. diminished. So, following through on our Friday here in the U.S.

The big heatwave, its deadly impact, and the call for help made by some police. And a fishing surprise, the incredible video of a real-life jaws. Wait for it encounter. Yes.

And millennials on the move. Find out top cities that they are flocking to. And a bull riding cop finds out the call that led to this officer. Well, giddy-up.

Our top story this half-hour. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, looking to wrap up a deal with the White House to lift the debt ceiling for Congress leaves for recess at the end of this week. That was one of the many topics, Maria, discussed within an exclusive sit-down with Bank of America chairman and CEO Brian Moynihan.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BARTIROMO: Here we are in the longest expansion anybody has ever seen. And we're dealing with potentially another government shutdown. Will that end this expansion? Will markets get disrupted by this?

BRIAN MOYNIHAN, CHAIRMAN, BANK OF AMERICA: Well, I think, first, I think everybody agrees it shouldn't happen. The problem is 18 months ago, everybody agreed it shouldn't happen in the fall of 17, and it happened.

And so, I think we have to be careful that the unintended consequence can happen. In the environment with which it might happen, this time it's not quite as strong as remember, coming in the early team, we had tax reform get passed and nobody thought it would happens. So, there's tremendous enthusiasm in the business community, it's a little different now.

And so I think that's why, you know, Secretary Mnuchin and Speaker Pelosi are working hard on it. I think their best intentions are not to have an issue but it affected economy in the first quarter of 18 and the debate is it could affect it again?

And I think that along with three or four things are needed to get resolved the correct way in order to keep this expansion go in the United States. And I think all of them are imminently solvable and they just got to get done.

BARTIROMO: Unbelievable. What else needs to get done, Brian?

MOYNIHAN: Well, first, you have to get the USMCA through. Because in any day, we have to stabilize that relationship between our north and south partners. And because it's good for all these -- all the countries I got a deal worked out, they just kind of push it through.

BARTIROMO: Yes, and by the way, if we can't get a deal that's already been agreed upon with our friends, imagine getting deals done with others?

MOYNIHAN: Yes. Well, because that brings it. So, you have that -- you have the debt ceiling that's kind of the fall issues to get make sure get done. Because I think that will send a signal to the world that the United States is pushing forward with agreements on trade.

And I think then, the next couple of issues, the one we got to get through the Brexit resolution, all this is in the general economy ultimately make sure it doesn't disrupt too much.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MOYNIHAN: And then we've got China to keep it from blowing up. You know, and there's very difficult issues there. And the business community around the world knows that this has to be resolved and is with the -- with the administration and others clearly saying, you know these are difficult issues.

But the issues, if it blows up, it could be a detriment. And so, you they need to keep it going along towards a positive result. I think both countries interest there. But if you take those three or four things, basically USMC, the debt ceiling Brexit, China.

If we can keep those in the right place, I think the economy in the U.S. will continue to progress well.

BARTIROMO: Really. OK, so, how does the backdrop feel to you right now? You just reported $7 billion in net income last week. What did that tell you, what did the corner highlight for you in terms of the strength and weakness in the economy today?

Well, if you look at what drives our earnings, it's all the -- its American economy and our great teammates work on that. So, our consumer business made $3 billion. Our global banking business which is company -- you know, corporate banking made $2 billion, and then, we made a billion in wealth management -- billion in markets. So, it's very spread around all good performance.

But the consumer business everybody is talking about, because in that, you're seeing a consumer who is very strong in the United States spending money, borrowing responsibly, they're employed, their wages are growing faster than people thought. You see three percent handles on that now.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MOYNIHAN: Their expectations are high, their confidence, although, not quite as high at the highest point, you know, still very high. All that is very good because the end of the day, two thirds the U.S. economy is by people like yourself spending money. And if you spend money, businesses will be successful, small business will be successful, and then, and will go on.

We look on the business side. Our small business loans outstanding are up from $35 to $37 billion every year, about six percent. The small business of borrowing -- again, their confidence dipped down a little bit, but that's because the world got more complex.

And if you look at mid-sized companies, they're spending a little less on CapEx, largely because that incentives are sort of through the system now. But they're very solid. Everybody is fine and sort of braced for please, as a please to move uncertainty and we can be more aggressive.

BARTIROMO: You know, I'm glad you said CapEx is OK. Because there's this debate about these uncertainties over China, USMCA are now keeping businesses sitting on cash. But they're still spending on technology and you're spending a lot on technology, I'll get to that in a second.

But you still think CapEx is OK. Businesses are all allocating money to important issues that they need.

MOYNIHAN: It's slowed down to about half the rate, but still there.

BARTIROMO: Right.

MOYNIHAN: But, the real question, it could be faster with that certainty. But people have sort of adjusted to the issues at the moment. And if you look at companies -- you talk to a company, anybody's in China is seeing a slowdown affect them. It's usually 20 percent of their business, 30 percent of business, and slow down, yet 20 percent. So, it's not the impact across the whole platform but it's the reverberation of that impact they're worried about. But generally, businesses are very saying what about what's going on. What's going to come?

It's amazing to me how efficient businesses have become in terms of the ability to deploy a modest amount of expense and get a lot of pop out of it like we do. We pay $3 billion in technology. We basically have flat expenses on our company for four years in a row.

And you think about that with multiple -- with transaction growth, six, seven, eight, 10 percent with Salesforce growth, you know, three, four, five percent a year in terms of new people.

We're able to pay for all that by investing technology and both for the customer and for ourselves to keep improving the company and our efficiency ratio has gone down. That's what businesses are doing around the world. You know, they're just -- they're learning how to become incrementally more efficient through all this wonderful technology and capabilities that they have.

BARTIROMO: Well, that's one of the ways you were able to turn this company around in the last decade. Because of your focus on keeping expenses tight or conservative as well as investing in technology.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

MCDOWELL: More of Maria's exclusive interview with Bank of America CEO Brian Moynihan, and coming up next hour. But first, a dangerous heat wave covering much of the country. Cheryl Casone has more. Hey, Cheryl.

CASONE: Yes, Dagen. So, an extreme heatwave is now blamed for, at least, six deaths from the Carolinas to Maine.

Daytime highs reached the upper 90s yesterday. Here in New York City, Con Ed reported that about 50,000 homes and businesses lost power, it's expected to cool off though as a cold front is slowly going to shift across the East. Police in a Massachusetts town asked residents to hold off on any criminal activity until today. So, there you have that. Thank you. You just wait to rob that bank today, no one will come out and arrest you.

All right, we have some jaw-dropping video for all the fishermen on the panel. OK, there's just one, of a great white shark, leaping out of the water and nearly biting a boy on a fishing boat. Look at this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DOUG NELSON, JOINED AN OUTING ON CAPE COD BAY: Oh, wow!

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Oh, my God.

CASONE: Yes. This is a very close call as you can see. This happened near Cape Cod. The shark jumped out of the water to steal a fish as it was being reeled in. Thankfully, nobody was hurt, well.

And then, there is this. Millennials are packing their bags for the West Coast. They are moving to cities with high home prices, a high cost of living, but also higher wages. It's according to a new study.

Portland, Oregon is the prime destination, followed by Seattle in Denver. San Francisco in Austin rounds out the top five.

I will send it back to you, Dagen. And, of course, the fisherman sitting next to you, probably. How I know I was on his boat yesterday.

MCDOWELL: I'm at shark site.

CASONE: I grew up fishing.

(CROSSTALK)

ROSCHELLE: I -- Yes, and so --

CARTER: Me two.

CASONE: And she's a fisherperson.

ROSCHELLE: So, at least a fisherperson is --

MCDOWELL: You're a fisherperson.

CASONE: A fisherperson.

ROSCHELLE: Just full disclosure, Lee, and I were trying to figure out what fish is being pulled into that the sharks was going after.

CARTER: A sad way (INAUDIBLE).

MCDOWELL: What do you think it was?

ROSCHELLE: I think it was a cod because it was on Cape Cod. But I think it was a cod. That was my guess. But audience will probably tweet at me tell me, I don't know what I'm talking about. But that was any working theory.

BLOCK: The Massachusetts stories were great. You know, the police department that Cheryl was referring to is Braintree, Massachusetts. And it was great because there was this great tweet that said, "It's -- you know, you have to say in Boston accident like, it was hotter than soccer balls out there. So -- Incredible tweet --

CARTER: Wait until tomorrow.

ROSCHELLE: That is a Jack Kennedy imitation

BLOCK: No, it's better -- I think -- I think it's like -- I think it's Mayor Quimby from the Simpsons, actually. Don't suppose to be honest.

MCDOWELL: You didn't sound like either Kennedy nor Quimby.

BLOCK: I'm from Stanton now, and so --

ROSCHELLE: Where (INAUDIBLE).

BLOCK: Hey, Chucky.

MCDOWELL: Mark Wahlberg. Coming up, the busiest week of earning season. Halliburton kicking things off today. Reporting moments from now, we bring you the numbers as soon as they break.

And this is not his first rodeo. A cop takes a ride on a mechanical bull at a house party.

MCDOWELL: Headlines across America this morning. The Pittsburgh Post- gazette reports this: "Dispute poll CBS off the air for DirecTV customers." CBS went to black on satellite systems owned by AT&T and New York, L.A., Chicago, and other cities across the U.S. including Pittsburgh. The network and AT&T mudslinging over the failure to agree on what CBS is paid for programming. The network warning this could be -- this could last a long time.

The Mercury News says that Google's big plans for downtown San Jose answers for all of your questions, plenty of questions and now some answers to how and when Google's takeover of San Jose will commence. Those plans include overhauling a city so-called sleepy downtown train station.

And then this, OzarksFirst.com writes: "A Texas police officer responded to a noise complaint and wound up riding mechanical bull." And here we go, this apparently was not his first rodeo. The cop answering this call did (INAUDIBLE), climbing on the bull at a house party in East Texas riding effortlessly for about 30 seconds. Before falling off -- he was rewarded with cheers and plenty of high-fives. A three-year-old could ride that bull, though. Just saying.

But we have breaking news for you. Halliburton earnings are out and Deirdre Bolton has everything you need to know.

DEIRDRE BOLTON, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: That's right, Dagen. If you look at earnings, you have a clear beat so that why we are seeing Halliburton move higher in the premarket. So, instead of $30.00 a share, which is what Wall Street was looking for the company posting $35.00 a share, so clear beat, obviously stronger. The problem for the company as day goes on, is going to be revenue a little light.

So, Wall Street looking for 5.97 billion in revenue. Halliburton posting 5.93 billion, so almost there, not quite, but as we can tell from the premarket, it seems like most investors are focusing on that profit number. So Dagen, we'll watch Halliburton also watch its large per competitor, Schlumberger -- won't be off to races. Back to you.

MCDOWEL: Deirdre, thank you so much. Deirdre Bolton on earnings for us. Coming up, the deep dive into Deepfakes. We take a look at the technology behind bogus videos and the potential political impact. Next.

MCDOWELL: Deepfake -- something you might have heard of. The technology allows anyone to create a video of an event that never happened and now that it's posing threat to business and our political system. Joining me now: Morning Anchor for Fox News Headlines 24/7 on SiriusXM 115, Brett Larson.

BRETT LARSON, FOX NEWS CHANNEL ANCHOR: This is terrifying, right? We've seen the videos -- there's a video of President Obama, I believe, he's praising President Trump. There's a video of Mark Zuckerberg saying I'm going it take Facebook off the Internet because that's right thing to do. Obviously, if you watch that video, you'd would think: wait, what now? But you might -- it might catch you off-guard and you might think it's real.

Now, we're hearing reports that they're using the same Deepfake technology to impersonate people's voices. So, we're taking about, you know, high- profile CEOs, to call their other executives and ask for money to help them out because they're in some sort of danger. It is a similar situation to - - that's if this is maybe something that we have experience of something -- I've experienced where a friend messages you on Facebook and says: hey, I'm in -- I'm traveling through Europe and I lost my passport and I need some cash because I'm at the hotel and all of my stuff is stolen.

And for a second, you might fall for it and think: well, that's interesting. The time it happened to me, I had happened to also have been in Europe, so I said: oh, my gosh, how convenient I'm also -- I'm in Paris. You know, where are you? But I have to point this out: you were just in New York yesterday. So, how is it that you're already in Europe and you've lost all of your stuff? So, obviously, the person who had hacked into that account was then on to me and I got blocked.

But what these guys are doing is taking speeches that CEO have given, ted talks, putting it into artificial intelligence and the just like Alexa, just like Siri, just like Google Home -- the voice has the ability to speak like another person and say anything you want.

MCDOWELL: Who's behind technology and more importantly the abuse of the technology?

LARSON: These are going to be some hard-core hackers who have figured some stuff out.

ROSCHELLE: Domestic or foreign?

LARSON: I would -- I'm going to go out on a limb and say probably foreign. Probably from those countries that we like to spar with. That, you know, computers are -- they work everywhere. Anywhere you can plug them in and access Internet, you can do this kind of stuff.

CARTER: It's really scary because they can put things out there that people are predisposed to believe.

LARSON: Right.

CARTER: And then, it can perpetuate itself and this is super, super dangerous stuff and people can't even tell the difference in print stories, but you see video and hear the audio --

ROSCHELLE: Then it's real.

CARTER: -- then it's real.

LARSON: Especially if it plays to your existing confirmation bias.

CARTER: Exactly.

LARSON: So, we're talking about, you know, imagine if you had a presidential candidate's voice impersonated and you could call into a talk show and you could go through an entire interview with somebody who may be not in on the joke. I mean, we live in a -- you know, there's 24 Democratic presidential candidates; there's one on the Republican side running who happens to also be in the White House. Imagine if you -- you know, you have a talk show and somebody says: oh, the president of the United States is on the phone and wants to talk to you. You're not going to say no to that and you're going to put them on the air and you're going to hear it, and think, well it sounds like the president.

MCDOWELL: You only need to make that mistake once and get (INAUDIBLE). It --

LARSON: That is absolutely true.

MCDOWELL: It happens.

LARSON: That is true.

MCDOWELL: With what love Howard Stern, that's no disrespect to Howard Stern.

LARSON: But you know it's an interesting -- I hate to say interesting time. It's kind of a frightening situation where you can do this.

MCDOWELL: What are the social media companies doing about it, though, ahead of the election particularly next year? The election is -- the campaigns are happening now; what are they doing about it now?

LARSON: What are they doing about this?

MCDOWELL: Nothing --

LARSON: You know, look, Facebook did the war room for the 2018 midterm elections where they tried to stay on top this stuff. This -- to me this feel like a toothpaste out of the tube situation where it's going to be -- we're just users now; it really falls on the users are going to have more savvy about what they hear and see.

CARTER: Well, these candidates are going to have to be really vigilant about --

LARSON: Well, absolutely.

CARTER: -- you know, protecting their messaging.

ROSCHELLE: I guess if it goes viral, then they can shut it down. It's the innocuous one that seems real that influences a small group of people, that's the danger.

LARSON: Right. Exactly. Or the, you know, we use this in a campaign phone call. We use fake audio of a candidate. And this could be a candidate for anything. It could be mayor or congress, or even president.

MCDOWELL: I'll end on this, though: the more this goes on and the more the social media companies have allowed, it's not just opinion it is literally fake manufactured news. It makes the -- the real media companies and the old newspapers much more relevant because more and more people are going to lean on them to -- again, it's the reporters' responsibility to vet and vet and vet and make sure something is real and accurate. I think it benefits the real media companies in this environment.

LARSON: Absolutely. And I've gotten a lot of flak for saying this in past but it is the rules of journalism: we have a gatekeeper. There is somebody who sits there and says hold on a second, they said what in a telephone interview? Let's fact check, double check, triple check before we go through that. Whereas, if you're blogger -- this is no offense to bloggers or Twitter-ers -- you just put it out there. You know, did you double check, did you call? Simple rules? 101. Journalism.

MCDOWELL: The Covington High School --

LARSON: Yes, take a class.

MCDOWELL: The Covington High School kids, you know who -- because you're on there and again it's like: I need to get in on app. No, I'm not. I'm putting my phone down because that doesn't look right. I was like there's a lot more to that story.

LARSON: Wait until the story is fully told.

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much, Brett Larson. Good to see you. Fox News Headlines 24/7 every morning, SiriusXM 115. Thanks, Brett. Still ahead, major earnings on tap. 10 Dow component this is week out with earnings ahead of the Fed, possibly cutting interest rates next week. Welcome wedding crasher. President Trump drops in on a New Jersey couple saying their vows over the weekend. Next hour, MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

urn:contentItem:5R6W-B4F1-DY0W-412H-00000-00Markets Close at Records Amid Tax Plan Hopes; 'Congratulations' for British Prime Minister as Brexit Advances; Europe Make Net Neutrality Offer2017-12-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:08:49ZLexisNexisMarkets Close at Records Amid Tax Plan Hopes; 'Congratulations' for British Prime Minister as Brexit Advances; Europe Make Net Neutrality OfferLanhamFULL TEXT

[16:00:00] RICHARD QUEST, CNN HOST: There we go. We've got records on the Dow, records on the Nasdaq, record high on the S&P 500. And we could have an all-time record for the number of records. Go on, yes, that's enough bell. To the business. Well, I suppose that's a firm gavel. Trading is over. It's Friday, it's December the 15th.

Tonight, records all around on Wall Street. As Republicans are closing in on their tax plan. Theresa May gets some congratulations as Brexit talks now formally go to stage two. And European politicians tell tech companies to cross the Atlantic in search of net neutrality. Europe is the place to be.

I'm Richard Quest, live in the world's financial capital. A rainy/snowy capital today, where I mean business.

Good evening. Tonight, volume is high, and so are the spirits on Wall Street. A record-breaking session to end the week, with all three major markets closing at an all-time high. And it comes as the Republicans in Congress are edging ever closer to an historic victory on their tax plan.

So, join me at the trading post as we put this into perspective. No question with the Dow, the S&P and the Nasdaq, we have green all across the board today. And with record highs. So how many records? Where do we stand so far, this year? The Dow now has 69 records. S&P, 61. And the Nasdaq has hit a record 71 times so far, this year. The Dow ends at a record -- it's the fourth time this week it's had this record. And the S&P with 61 is on track to have made gains every month this year. If that happens, and it looks like it will by the end of the month, then that will be the first time in history that it's happened.

Now, one of the reasons why we saw extreme volatility during the course of the day was its quadruple witching day at the New York Stock Exchange. What that means is options, futures and cash market, various contracts, all expire at the same time. And when you put it like that, then you manage to get huge volatility. For example, the best part of 200 million shares had changed hands just the open alone. And we were heading towards 600, 700 million by the close of trading today.

Europe still lags somewhat on the record. We haven't had any really new -- we haven't had any new all-time highs on the FTSE, the DAX or the CAC for some time. Speaking to me earlier on the trading floor of the New York Stock Exchange, the global head of listings told me it had been a strong year all around, reinforced when you look at those numbers.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

JOHN TUTTLE, GLOBAL HEAD OF LISTINGS, NEW YORK STOCK EXCHANGE: It's been a strong year for U.S. capital markets. It's been a great year for the New York Stock Exchange. Last year, worst year in over a decade for capital- raising, equity capital-raising. This year we had 88 new listings on the New York Stock Exchange, raised more than double we did last year. And the pipeline for next year is strong, too.

QUEST: Why do you think that is? What is it about -- I mean, or is it just one of the things that goes in cycles and favors?
