urn:contentItem:60N0-64X1-F03R-N2ND-00000-00MarketWatch First Take: California makes bold moves to tackle Big Tech with Uber and Lyft showdown2020-08-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:08:49ZLexisNexisMarketWatch First Take: California makes bold moves to tackle Big Tech with Uber and Lyft showdownFinancial Press

Aug 21, 2020( Financial Press: https://financialpress.com/ Delivered by Newstex) MarketWatch First Take Published: Aug. 20, 2020 at 10:24 p.m. ET Ride-hailing companies win temporary reprieve, but battle is not over yet Uber and Lyft are pitted in battle with the state of California. Getty Images As California becomes one of the first states to take on Big Tech in the ongoing battle over the employment status of Uber and Lyft drivers, the scofflaw ride-hailing companies are now working their political contacts to avoid complying with a law that has been on the books for almost a year.Earlier Thursday, an appellate judge granted an emergency stay, lifting the injunctions [1]

http://www.marketwatch.com/story/judge-denies-delay-for-uber-and-lyft-which-could-result-in-california-ride-hailing-shutdown-11597347579?mod=article_inlinehttp://www.marketwatch.com/story/judge-denies-delay-for-uber-and-lyft-which-could-result-in-california-ride-hailing-shutdown-11597347579?mod=article_inlinehttp://www.marketwatch.com/story/judge-denies-delay-for-uber-and-lyft-which-could-result-in-california-ride-hailing-shutdown-11597347579?mod=article_inlineagainstUber Technologies Inc.UBER, +6.76%[2] and Lyft Inc.LYFT, +5.75%[3] LYFT, +5.75%[4] that ordered them to comply with the California law, known as AB-5, that requires ride-hailing companies to classify their drivers as employees instead of independent contractors. The companies had threatened to shut operations in the state rather than comply with the ruling. They now have an expedited time frame for their appeals, which, in an unusual request from Appellate Judge P.J. Pollack, will now be consolidated. Both Uber and Lyft have until Aug. 25 to agree to the expedited procedures and then until Sept. 4 to file their opening briefs. The two companies, but Uber even more so, have taken an act-first-and-seek-forgiveness-later approach when it comes to complying with international and local regulations. Now, both are using all the political might that they have gathered up over the past years to buy more time in this battle, in the hopes that a ballot measure in the upcoming November election, known as Proposition 22, will overturn AB-5. The companies are spending millions of dollars fighting a law that will make their operating costs rise if they are forced to pay benefits to their drivers. Their threats to shut down their operations in the state raised enough concern to get support in some corners. Late Wednesday, the mayors of San Jose and San Diego issued a joint statement[5], saying they had serious concerns that nearly 1 million gig-economy workers in California would lose their jobs if Uber and Lyft shut down their operations in the Golden State. They also played the pandemic card, saying that many of those drivers are helping homebound seniors and transporting patients seeking medical care. In their statement, they asked the appeals court to stay the injunction against the companies. 'The vast majority of drivers want to stay independent workers and are looking for solutions that protect their independence while also providing additional benefit,' said Kevin Faulconer, mayor of San Diego, and Sam Licardo, mayor of San Jose, echoing the party line of the companies. In addition, Uber and Lyft — along with DoorDash — have spent at least $30 million each so far on Prop. 22, which would exempt them from AB-5. So while the state ushered in a new law that offers more protections to workers, the companies involved have been doing everything possible to make their part of the gig as low-cost and as high-profit as possible. Instead of preparing for a major change, and making changes in their operations to accommodate the new law, they have continued to relentlessly fight it. The appellate judge, however, is demanding that the CEOs of both companies submit a sworn statement, also by Sept. 4, 'confirming that it [the company] has developed implementation plans under which, if this court affirms the preliminary injunction and Proposition 22 on the November 2020 ballot fails to pass.' California is leading the way in these battles against Big Tech, from this fight with Uber and Lyft to the California Consumer Protection Act (CCPA) that is Facebook [6]Inc.'s FB, +2.44%[7] next nightmare, to a law requiring women on company boards. And just last week, a new bill that would require racial diversity on boards passed the state Senate Committee on Banking and Financial Institutions. [8] Whether these efforts to reign in tech giants will be successful or not is way too early to tell, but it's clear that the rest of the U.S. is watching. The Uber and Lyft showdown is an important battle in the war against the dominance of Big Tech. The post MarketWatch First Take: California makes bold moves to tackle Big Tech with Uber and Lyft showdown[9] appeared first on Financial Press[10]. urn:contentItem:5RCX-H021-F15W-H19H-00000-00MARK HAWTIN, INVESTMENT DIRECTOR, GAM, IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TELEVISION2018-01-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:08:49ZLexisNexisMARK HAWTIN, INVESTMENT DIRECTOR, GAM, IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TELEVISION

January 11, 2018

NEWS PROGRAM

MARK HAWTIN, INVESTMENT DIRECTOR, GAM,

LEVINE: Let's prospects in 2018 in these asset classes. Joining us now London is Mark Hawtin, Investment Director at GAM. Mark, what do you think about really the story of the day, I've had to say is the prospect of rising yields?

HAWTIN: I think it's an interesting term. We've had a really strong start to markets in the first week of January. There are clearly some issues that investors are beginning to look at. But for me, I think one needs to guide in the inflation outlook. It's all going to be about how the inflation prints come through from a fundamental points of view unless the market might be positioning for worse inflation data. I think that from a fundamental perspective, that's what needs to be focused on most and Friday obviously is a key day for that.

JOHNSON: Yes, U.S. CPI will deliver it on Friday. If inflation starts to tick higher, if yields start to go higher, how does that change how I invest in equities?

HAWTIN: Well, I think it will have an impact. Always when market move away from the perceived view, you get changes. So I think the initial position will be that markets will probably sell off if we get a big tick up in yields and inflation data comes through stronger than expected. But I think as long as it's measured, equities will still be OK in the medium to longer term.

LEVINE: Isn't that the trade-off, Mark? I mean, if I'm sitting here with cash to put to work, the last thing I want to do is put it in bonds if we're looking at a bear market here, especially if I'm not going to get any return anyway. The only place to go is equities.

HAWTIN: Yes, I mean, obviously as an equity investor, I'd have to agree with that. But I think what tends to happen is that when you get the kind of shock effect initially, it affects all asset classes. So I think it will actually give you probably a better opportunity on a very short-term basis, perhaps a better to buy because it's all a bit cheaper.

JOHNSON: But in terms of how I position within the market -- I want to get this chart up so I can show you what is going on here. If rates go higher, how does that affect my kind of cyclical value balance? Cyclicals have been doing relatively well. Financial -- you saw it yesterday in the S&P, markets sold kind of bond proxies and bought into financials, et cetera. Is that the rotation that you would now expect to start to really sort of gain even more traction?

HAWTIN: I'm not sure. I think in General, cyclical assets and growth assets actually tend to do quite well in rising rate environment --

JOHNSON: OK.

HAWTIN: -- because we're seeing continued and stronger growth than expected coming through. So apart again from the initial shock factor, I think we will see growth assets in particular doing very well in a steady raising right environment.

JOHNSON: But it's all about the delta, it's all about the rate of change?

HAWTIN: Correct.

JOHNSON: And in terms of how does this work from my geographical point of view, is -- the U.S. is later in the cycle. Do I kind of rethink what I'm doing in the U.S. versus what's happening in Europe? Europe doesn't have much tech. We'll talk about tech a little bit later on. Is that a hindrance in this kind of environment? How do I position myself around the world?

HAWTIN: Well, I think we've already seen from the U.S. equity point of view, we've obviously already seen the tightening cycle beginning. So some of the shock factor is already built in there. If we were to start to see that occurring in Europe or in Japan, then you've probably got the shock factor to come. So mostly it's counterintuitive, but I would probably say the U.S. equities.

LEVINE: When I look at the possibility of buying equities, I always think from a value perspective maybe that is because I'm a bargain hunter by nature. U.S. equities seem to be pretty highly valued, I think 20 -- the last time I checked, 23 times forward earnings compared to 15 or 16 times forwards earnings here in Europe. I realize there's a mix difference, right, more tech stocks in the U.S. But what do you think about value hunting in this market?

HAWTIN: OK. So I think you've got to stick to, you know, strong fundamental work. And if you look within, I mean from the sector I cover which is technology, so the sector I have the most knowledge about, I can see that certain parts of that sector look quite stretched compared to history. Semiconductors, for example, where (INAUDIBLE) supposed have gone up to well over 13 times from a low in 2011 in 5.5 times. So there you had a big valuation increase.

But if you look at big cap tech more broadly, it's actually trading relative to the S&P at the lower end of its range because some of these big growth facets, these big growth countries have not rerated. In fact, according to a piece of research by Bernstein put out over the term of the year, big cap tech has actually derated slightly in the last 12 months in spite of share price performance.

LEVINE: All right, thanks very much, Mark.

HAWTIN: OK.

LEVINE: We're going to continue to talk about the technology side of that as well. Glad you mentioned that because we're going to focus in on it. Guy?

JOHNSON: Yes, absolutely, that is what's coming up.

(BREAK)

JOHNSON: Mark Hawtin is still with us, GAM Investment Director. Let's talk about tech kind of -- let's take a step back and kind of away from CES and the razzle-dazzle of what is going on there. Tech just had a great run. Is it going to continue to have a great run in 2018 and do I need to be even more concentrated in the way that I hold tech because (INAUDIBLE) this morning basically what it seems you are saying is that FANGS are going to continue to do well. But other areas, semis, et cetera may have such a great year.

HAWTIN: Yes. So this is my view. I think that overall, technology is not as overvalued as you might think, looking at how shares performed last year because earnings growth was extremely strong.

JOHNSON: Yes.

HAWTIN: But it's differentiated within the sector. So for example, some of the really big cap incumbent technology companies, companies like Cisco or IBM or some of the semis companies have very pedestrian growth but their share price performance are still strong. So they got heavily rerated.

JOHNSON: Yes.

HAWTIN: Some of the FANG names, their growth was actually faster than their share price performance so they actually got slightly derated. So I think they're going to be more and more selective in favor of growth and away from what's perceived as value. And that might well tie in as well with any chance we'll start to get in bond yields because I think investors will are tended to go for dividend yielding tech companies and that will become less attractive as rates rise.

JOHNSON: What does that mean for companies like Microsoft?

HAWTIN: I think Microsoft struggles almost directly between the two in a sense. It's got some great growth initiatives particularly with its public crowd offering.

JOHNSON: Yes.

HAWTIN: It has some incumbent businesses. It has a yield.

JOHNSON: Throws off a lot of cash too.

HAWTIN: Throws off a lot of cash. I think it probably sits in between the two. I still quite like it as an investment amongst that incumbent group.

JOHNSON: Why don't you like Apple?

HAWTIN: OK. So it is a tricky one because it's cheap. Apple is cheap.

JOHNSON: Yes.

HAWTIN: And if I was a pension fund manager, I'd probably be more seriously considering it as the kind of company to have in the portfolio. But as a growth technology company, it's far from growth to be honest. Expectations of growth over the next couple years is a low single digit top line. If the X is actually less successful than is expected, and that seems to be what's panning out here, then actually growth could be full even lower than that. So it's going to be a low to no growth company with a number I think of longer term risks.

JOHNSON: It feels in many ways a bit like kind of Microsoft a few years ago. It's kind of not generating a lot of top line growth but it's kind of kicking off a lot of cash and in many ways it depends on what kind of investor you are as to your attitude to whether or not you own it.

HAWTIN: It does and it does depend on what they do to change their business roadmap.

JOHNSON: Yes.

HAWTIN: And I think, you know, since the iPhone, there's not been an enormous amount of innovation. And even where there has been innovation, the opportunity for those innovative changes to create additional significant revenue are very limited against this massive sort of iceberg of iPhone unit sales. So I think that, you know, everyone is focusing on the service business now but that's coming under a lot of competitive pressure from companies like Amazon Prime Video, for example on the iTunes side.

JOHNSON: One thing that people talk about when they talk about big tech is the regulatory risk. And we were talking about this yesterday on the program. It feels like we're coming out of a kind of 15-year regulatory cram down for the telecom sector. Is there a discount that I need to apply coming back to phase (ph) to some of these stocks because of the potential regulatory position that we may be getting over the next few years? And is that why the market almost did what it did last year? It's beginning to kind of factor in external factors other than simply what they can do in terms of top and bottom line and kind of what the bigger trajectory is here? Like Mark Zuckerberg talks about this year, he's got to fix Facebook. From the investor point of view, that sounds quite serious.

HAWTIN: Yes. Well, he would say that obviously because he needs to make sure that he is saying the right things.

JOHNSON: Yes.

HAWTIN: As such a large company, it's important that he is seen to be politically correct. And, you know, they are hiring another 15,000 people this year to monitor content and they're going to spend a lot of money doing that.

But I think that -- I think a lot of it has been factored in already and I think you're dead right. One of the reason why these growth names perhaps didn't do better last year was because of this perceived regulatory risk. But I think it will be an evolutionary factor. I don't think we're going to have a crashing down of regulation, which is going to heavily constrict these companies because to do that, quite frankly, it needs to be done on a global scale. And I cannot see a global initiative to crack down on the regulation of these businesses and no one country is going to want to risk being too aggressive themselves because then they risk vulcanizing themselves.

JOHNSON: So the Europeans who don't really have a tech sector to worry about.

HAWTIN: No, but they do I think realize that the internet is a vital part of their economy. The digital economy is becoming, you know, in many ways is because the physical economy. If you decide as one geographic unit to clamp down from a regulatory perspective and you risk the internet growth in your area, you're vulcanizing yourself and it could have long reaching consequences.

JOHNSON: Just from a kind of asset allocation point of view, do I overweight Asia and underweight Europe? Just kind of in sort of big picture here because of the fact that Asia has better tech companies and Europe doesn't have many. You've kind of named a couple already, SAP and so forth. But there aren't many. Is that a reason to be underweight Europe in 2018 do you think?

HAWTIN: I don't think it's right to make a decision on geographic allocation purely on how tech will do. And if you were going to make that decision, then you just continue to stick with the U.S.

JOHNSON: Right.

HAWTIN: I think it's interesting that although there's a perception that Asia is full of amazing technology companies, in reality, there are very few global leaders in Asia. There are some big players from a regional perspective, like the internet companies in China, but there are more global technology winners in Europe than there are in Asia. You know, there's SAP, there's SML leading their parts of the market.

JOHNSON: Right.

HAWTIN: There are very few real global leaders in Asia.

JOHNSON: Great to see you this morning, Mark. Thank you very much indeed --

HAWTIN: Thanks.

JOHNSON: -- for coming to see us here at Bloomberg. Mark Hawtin, Investment Director joining us from GAM on the tech sec.

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5RCY-PCY1-DY0W-4451-00000-00Mark Hawtin is interviewed on BB TV.2018-01-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:08:49ZLexisNexisMark Hawtin is interviewed on BB TV.WalthamFULL TEXT

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

MARK HAWTIN, INVESTMENT DIRECTOR, GAM, IS INTERVIEWED ON BB TV

JANUARY 10, 2018

SPEAKERS: MARK HAWTIN, INVESTMENT DIRECTOR, GAM

GUY JOHNSON, BLOOMBERG NEWS

MATT LEVINE, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] MATT LEVINE, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Let's prospects in 2018 in these asset classes. Joining us now London is Mark Hawtin, Investment Director at GAM. Mark, what do you think about really the story of the day, I've had to say is the prospect of rising yields?

MARK HAWTIN, INVESTMENT DIRECTOR, GAM: I think it's an interesting term. We've had a really strong start to markets in the first week of January. There are clearly some issues that investors are beginning to look at. But for me, I think one needs to guide in the inflation outlook. It's all going to be about how the inflation prints come through from a fundamental points of view unless the market might be positioning for worse inflation data. I think that from a fundamental perspective, that's what needs to be focused on most and Friday obviously is a key day for that.

GUY JOHNSON, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Yes, U.S. CPI will deliver it on Friday. If inflation starts to tick higher, if yields start to go higher, how does that change how I invest in equities?

HAWTIN: Well, I think it will have an impact. Always when market move away from the perceived view, you get changes. So I think the initial position will be that markets will probably sell off if we get a big tick up in yields and inflation data comes through stronger than expected. But I think as long as it's measured, equities will still be OK in the medium to longer term.

LEVINE: Isn't that the trade-off, Mark? I mean, if I'm sitting here with cash to put to work, the last thing I want to do is put it in bonds if we're looking at a bear market here, especially if I'm not going to get any return anyway. The only place to go is equities.

HAWTIN: Yes, I mean, obviously as an equity investor, I'd have to agree with that. But I think what tends to happen is that when you get the kind of shock effect initially, it affects all asset classes. So I think it will actually give you probably a better opportunity on a very short-term basis, perhaps a better to buy because it's all a bit cheaper.

JOHNSON: But in terms of how I position within the market -- I want to get this chart up so I can show you what is going on here. If rates go higher, how does that affect my kind of cyclical value balance? Cyclicals have been doing relatively well. Financial -- you saw it yesterday in the S&P, markets sold kind of bond proxies and bought into financials, et cetera. Is that the rotation that you would now expect to start to really sort of gain even more traction?

HAWTIN: I'm not sure. I think in General, cyclical assets and growth assets actually tend to do quite well in rising rate environment --

JOHNSON: OK.

HAWTIN: -- because we're seeing continued and stronger growth than expected coming through. So apart again from the initial shock factor, I think we will see growth assets in particular doing very well in a steady raising right environment.

JOHNSON: But it's all about the delta, it's all about the rate of change?

HAWTIN: Correct.

JOHNSON: And in terms of how does this work from my geographical point of view, is -- the U.S. is later in the cycle. Do I kind of rethink what I'm doing in the U.S. versus what's happening in Europe? Europe doesn't have much tech. We'll talk about tech a little bit later on. Is that a hindrance in this kind of environment? How do I position myself around the world?

HAWTIN: Well, I think we've already seen from the U.S. equity point of view, we've obviously already seen the tightening cycle beginning. So some of the shock factor is already built in there. If we were to start to see that occurring in Europe or in Japan, then you've probably got the shock factor to come. So mostly it's counterintuitive, but I would probably say the U.S. equities.

LEVINE: When I look at the possibility of buying equities, I always think from a value perspective maybe that is because I'm a bargain hunter by nature. U.S. equities seem to be pretty highly valued, I think 20 -- the last time I checked, 23 times forward earnings compared to 15 or 16 times forwards earnings here in Europe. I realize there's a mix difference, right, more tech stocks in the U.S. But what do you think about value hunting in this market?

HAWTIN: OK. So I think you've got to stick to, you know, strong fundamental work. And if you look within, I mean from the sector I cover which is technology, so the sector I have the most knowledge about, I can see that certain parts of that sector look quite stretched compared to history. Semiconductors, for example, where (INAUDIBLE) supposed have gone up to well over 13 times from a low in 2011 in 5.5 times. So there you had a big valuation increase.

But if you look at big cap tech more broadly, it's actually trading relative to the S&P at the lower end of its range because some of these big growth facets, these big growth countries have not rerated. In fact, according to a piece of research by Bernstein put out over the term of the year, big cap tech has actually derated slightly in the last 12 months in spite of share price performance.

LEVINE: All right, thanks very much, Mark.

HAWTIN: OK.

LEVINE: We're going to continue to talk about the technology side of that as well. Glad you mentioned that because we're going to focus in on it. Guy?

JOHNSON: Yes, absolutely, that is what's coming up.

(BREAK)

JOHNSON: Mark Hawtin is still with us, GAM Investment Director. Let's talk about tech kind of -- let's take a step back and kind of away from CES and the razzle-dazzle of what is going on there. Tech just had a great run. Is it going to continue to have a great run in 2018 and do I need to be even more concentrated in the way that I hold tech because (INAUDIBLE) this morning basically what it seems you are saying is that FANGS are going to continue to do well. But other areas, semis, et cetera may have such a great year.

HAWTIN: Yes. So this is my view. I think that overall, technology is not as overvalued as you might think, looking at how shares performed last year because earnings growth was extremely strong.

JOHNSON: Yes.

HAWTIN: But it's differentiated within the sector. So for example, some of the really big cap incumbent technology companies, companies like Cisco or IBM or some of the semis companies have very pedestrian growth but their share price performance are still strong. So they got heavily rerated.

JOHNSON: Yes.

HAWTIN: Some of the FANG names, their growth was actually faster than their share price performance so they actually got slightly derated. So I think they're going to be more and more selective in favor of growth and away from what's perceived as value. And that might well tie in as well with any chance we'll start to get in bond yields because I think investors will are tended to go for dividend yielding tech companies and that will become less attractive as rates rise.

JOHNSON: What does that mean for companies like Microsoft?

HAWTIN: I think Microsoft struggles almost directly between the two in a sense. It's got some great growth initiatives particularly with its public crowd offering.

JOHNSON: Yes.

HAWTIN: It has some incumbent businesses. It has a yield.

JOHNSON: Throws off a lot of cash too.

HAWTIN: Throws off a lot of cash. I think it probably sits in between the two. I still quite like it as an investment amongst that incumbent group.

JOHNSON: Why don't you like Apple?

HAWTIN: OK. So it is a tricky one because it's cheap. Apple is cheap.

JOHNSON: Yes.

HAWTIN: And if I was a pension fund manager, I'd probably be more seriously considering it as the kind of company to have in the portfolio. But as a growth technology company, it's far from growth to be honest. Expectations of growth over the next couple years is a low single digit top line. If the X is actually less successful than is expected, and that seems to be what's panning out here, then actually growth could be full even lower than that. So it's going to be a low to no growth company with a number I think of longer term risks.

JOHNSON: It feels in many ways a bit like kind of Microsoft a few years ago. It's kind of not generating a lot of top line growth but it's kind of kicking off a lot of cash and in many ways it depends on what kind of investor you are as to your attitude to whether or not you own it.

HAWTIN: It does and it does depend on what they do to change their business roadmap.

JOHNSON: Yes.

HAWTIN: And I think, you know, since the iPhone, there's not been an enormous amount of innovation. And even where there has been innovation, the opportunity for those innovative changes to create additional significant revenue are very limited against this massive sort of iceberg of iPhone unit sales. So I think that, you know, everyone is focusing on the service business now but that's coming under a lot of competitive pressure from companies like Amazon Prime Video, for example on the iTunes side.

JOHNSON: One thing that people talk about when they talk about big tech is the regulatory risk. And we were talking about this yesterday on the program. It feels like we're coming out of a kind of 15-year regulatory cram down for the telecom sector. Is there a discount that I need to apply coming back to phase (ph) to some of these stocks because of the potential regulatory position that we may be getting over the next few years? And is that why the market almost did what it did last year? It's beginning to kind of factor in external factors other than simply what they can do in terms of top and bottom line and kind of what the bigger trajectory is here? Like Mark Zuckerberg talks about this year, he's got to fix Facebook. From the investor point of view, that sounds quite serious.

HAWTIN: Yes. Well, he would say that obviously because he needs to make sure that he is saying the right things.

JOHNSON: Yes.

HAWTIN: As such a large company, it's important that he is seen to be politically correct. And, you know, they are hiring another 15,000 people this year to monitor content and they're going to spend a lot of money doing that.

But I think that -- I think a lot of it has been factored in already and I think you're dead right. One of the reason why these growth names perhaps didn't do better last year was because of this perceived regulatory risk. But I think it will be an evolutionary factor. I don't think we're going to have a crashing down of regulation, which is going to heavily constrict these companies because to do that, quite frankly, it needs to be done on a global scale. And I cannot see a global initiative to crack down on the regulation of these businesses and no one country is going to want to risk being too aggressive themselves because then they risk vulcanizing themselves.

JOHNSON: So the Europeans who don't really have a tech sector to worry about.

HAWTIN: No, but they do I think realize that the internet is a vital part of their economy. The digital economy is becoming, you know, in many ways is because the physical economy. If you decide as one geographic unit to clamp down from a regulatory perspective and you risk the internet growth in your area, you're vulcanizing yourself and it could have long reaching consequences.

JOHNSON: Just from a kind of asset allocation point of view, do I overweight Asia and underweight Europe? Just kind of in sort of big picture here because of the fact that Asia has better tech companies and Europe doesn't have many. You've kind of named a couple already, SAP and so forth. But there aren't many. Is that a reason to be underweight Europe in 2018 do you think?

HAWTIN: I don't think it's right to make a decision on geographic allocation purely on how tech will do. And if you were going to make that decision, then you just continue to stick with the U.S.

JOHNSON: Right.

HAWTIN: I think it's interesting that although there's a perception that Asia is full of amazing technology companies, in reality, there are very few global leaders in Asia. There are some big players from a regional perspective, like the internet companies in China, but there are more global technology winners in Europe than there are in Asia. You know, there's SAP, there's SML leading their parts of the market.

JOHNSON: Right.

HAWTIN: There are very few real global leaders in Asia.

JOHNSON: Great to see you this morning, Mark. Thank you very much indeed --

HAWTIN: Thanks.

JOHNSON: -- for coming to see us here at Bloomberg. Mark Hawtin, Investment Director joining us from GAM on the tech sec.

[*]

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

It's beginning to kind of factor in external factors other than simply what they can do in terms of top and bottom line and kind of what the bigger trajectory is here? Like Mark Zuckerberg talks about this year, he's got to fix Facebook. From the investor point of view, that sounds quite serious.

HAWTIN: Yes. Well, he would say that obviously because he needs to make sure that he is saying the right things.

JOHNSON: Yes.

HAWTIN: As such a large company, it's important that he is seen to be politically correct. And, you know, they are hiring another 15,000 people this year to monitor content and they're going to spend a lot of money doing that.

But I think that -- I think a lot of it has been factored in already and I think you're dead right. One of the reason why these growth names perhaps didn't do better last year was because of this perceived regulatory risk. But I think it will be an evolutionary factor. I don't think we're going to have a crashing down of regulation, which is going to heavily constrict these companies because to do that, quite frankly, it needs to be done on a global scale. And I cannot see a global initiative to crack down on the regulation of these businesses and no one country is going to want to risk being too aggressive themselves because then they risk vulcanizing themselves.

JOHNSON: So the Europeans who don't really have a tech sector to worry about.

HAWTIN: No, but they do I think realize that the internet is a vital part of their economy. The digital economy is becoming, you know, in many ways is because the physical economy. If you decide as one geographic unit to clamp down from a regulatory perspective and you risk the internet growth in your area, you're vulcanizing yourself and it could have long reaching consequences.

JOHNSON: Just from a kind of asset allocation point of view, do I overweight Asia and underweight Europe? Just kind of in sort of big picture here because of the fact that Asia has better tech companies and Europe doesn't have many. You've kind of named a couple already, SAP and so forth. But there aren't many. Is that a reason to be underweight Europe in 2018 do you think?

HAWTIN: I don't think it's right to make a decision on geographic allocation purely on how tech will do. And if you were going to make that decision, then you just continue to stick with the U.S.

JOHNSON: Right.

HAWTIN: I think it's interesting that although there's a perception that Asia is full of amazing technology companies, in reality, there are very few global leaders in Asia. There are some big players from a regional perspective, like the internet companies in China, but there are more global technology winners in Europe than there are in Asia. You know, there's SAP, there's SML leading their parts of the market.

JOHNSON: Right.

HAWTIN: There are very few real global leaders in Asia.

JOHNSON: Great to see you this morning, Mark. Thank you very much indeed --

HAWTIN: Thanks.

JOHNSON: -- for coming to see us here at Bloomberg. Mark Hawtin, Investment Director joining us from GAM on the tech sec.

[*]

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5RCS-GWM1-DXH2-61XK-00000-00Mark Hawtin is interviewed on BB TV.2018-01-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:08:49ZLexisNexisBLOOMBERG TV12:00 AM ESTMark Hawtin, Guy JohnsonNEWSInternational011094cb.550Mark Hawtin is interviewed on BB TV.Matt Levine

Mark Hawtin discusses economics.

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

MARK HAWTIN, INVESTMENT DIRECTOR, GAM, IS INTERVIEWED ON BB TV

JANUARY 10, 2018

SPEAKERS: MARK HAWTIN, INVESTMENT DIRECTOR, GAM

GUY JOHNSON, BLOOMBERG NEWS

MATT LEVINE, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] MATT LEVINE, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Let's prospects in 2018 in these asset classes. Joining us now London is Mark Hawtin, Investment Director at GAM. Mark, what do you think about really the story of the day, I've had to say is the prospect of rising yields?

MARK HAWTIN, INVESTMENT DIRECTOR, GAM: I think it's an interesting term. We've had a really strong start to markets in the first week of January. There are clearly some issues that investors are beginning to look at. But for me, I think one needs to guide in the inflation outlook. It's all going to be about how the inflation prints come through from a fundamental points of view unless the market might be positioning for worse inflation data. I think that from a fundamental perspective, that's what needs to be focused on most and Friday obviously is a key day for that.

GUY JOHNSON, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Yes, U.S. CPI will deliver it on Friday. If inflation starts to tick higher, if yields start to go higher, how does that change how I invest in equities?

HAWTIN: Well, I think it will have an impact. Always when market move away from the perceived view, you get changes. So I think the initial position will be that markets will probably sell off if we get a big tick up in yields and inflation data comes through stronger than expected. But I think as long as it's measured, equities will still be OK in the medium to longer term.

LEVINE: Isn't that the trade-off, Mark? I mean, if I'm sitting here with cash to put to work, the last thing I want to do is put it in bonds if we're looking at a bear market here, especially if I'm not going to get any return anyway. The only place to go is equities.

HAWTIN: Yes, I mean, obviously as an equity investor, I'd have to agree with that. But I think what tends to happen is that when you get the kind of shock effect initially, it affects all asset classes. So I think it will actually give you probably a better opportunity on a very short-term basis, perhaps a better to buy because it's all a bit cheaper.

JOHNSON: But in terms of how I position within the market -- I want to get this chart up so I can show you what is going on here. If rates go higher, how does that affect my kind of cyclical value balance? Cyclicals have been doing relatively well. Financial -- you saw it yesterday in the S&P, markets sold kind of bond proxies and bought into financials, et cetera. Is that the rotation that you would now expect to start to really sort of gain even more traction?

HAWTIN: I'm not sure. I think in General, cyclical assets and growth assets actually tend to do quite well in rising rate environment --

JOHNSON: OK.

HAWTIN: -- because we're seeing continued and stronger growth than expected coming through. So apart again from the initial shock factor, I think we will see growth assets in particular doing very well in a steady raising right environment.

JOHNSON: But it's all about the delta, it's all about the rate of change?

HAWTIN: Correct.

JOHNSON: And in terms of how does this work from my geographical point of view, is -- the U.S. is later in the cycle. Do I kind of rethink what I'm doing in the U.S. versus what's happening in Europe? Europe doesn't have much tech. We'll talk about tech a little bit later on. Is that a hindrance in this kind of environment? How do I position myself around the world?

HAWTIN: Well, I think we've already seen from the U.S. equity point of view, we've obviously already seen the tightening cycle beginning. So some of the shock factor is already built in there. If we were to start to see that occurring in Europe or in Japan, then you've probably got the shock factor to come. So mostly it's counterintuitive, but I would probably say the U.S. equities.

LEVINE: When I look at the possibility of buying equities, I always think from a value perspective maybe that is because I'm a bargain hunter by nature. U.S. equities seem to be pretty highly valued, I think 20 -- the last time I checked, 23 times forward earnings compared to 15 or 16 times forwards earnings here in Europe. I realize there's a mix difference, right, more tech stocks in the U.S. But what do you think about value hunting in this market?

HAWTIN: OK. So I think you've got to stick to, you know, strong fundamental work. And if you look within, I mean from the sector I cover which is technology, so the sector I have the most knowledge about, I can see that certain parts of that sector look quite stretched compared to history. Semiconductors, for example, where (INAUDIBLE) supposed have gone up to well over 13 times from a low in 2011 in 5.5 times. So there you had a big valuation increase.

But if you look at big cap tech more broadly, it's actually trading relative to the S&P at the lower end of its range because some of these big growth facets, these big growth countries have not rerated. In fact, according to a piece of research by Bernstein put out over the term of the year, big cap tech has actually derated slightly in the last 12 months in spite of share price performance.

LEVINE: All right, thanks very much, Mark.

HAWTIN: OK.

LEVINE: We're going to continue to talk about the technology side of that as well. Glad you mentioned that because we're going to focus in on it. Guy?

JOHNSON: Yes, absolutely, that is what's coming up.

(BREAK)

JOHNSON: Mark Hawtin is still with us, GAM Investment Director. Let's talk about tech kind of -- let's take a step back and kind of away from CES and the razzle-dazzle of what is going on there. Tech just had a great run. Is it going to continue to have a great run in 2018 and do I need to be even more concentrated in the way that I hold tech because (INAUDIBLE) this morning basically what it seems you are saying is that FANGS are going to continue to do well. But other areas, semis, et cetera may have such a great year.

HAWTIN: Yes. So this is my view. I think that overall, technology is not as overvalued as you might think, looking at how shares performed last year because earnings growth was extremely strong.

JOHNSON: Yes.

HAWTIN: But it's differentiated within the sector. So for example, some of the really big cap incumbent technology companies, companies like Cisco or IBM or some of the semis companies have very pedestrian growth but their share price performance are still strong. So they got heavily rerated.

JOHNSON: Yes.

HAWTIN: Some of the FANG names, their growth was actually faster than their share price performance so they actually got slightly derated. So I think they're going to be more and more selective in favor of growth and away from what's perceived as value. And that might well tie in as well with any chance we'll start to get in bond yields because I think investors will are tended to go for dividend yielding tech companies and that will become less attractive as rates rise.

JOHNSON: What does that mean for companies like Microsoft?

HAWTIN: I think Microsoft struggles almost directly between the two in a sense. It's got some great growth initiatives particularly with its public crowd offering.

JOHNSON: Yes.

HAWTIN: It has some incumbent businesses. It has a yield.

JOHNSON: Throws off a lot of cash too.

HAWTIN: Throws off a lot of cash. I think it probably sits in between the two. I still quite like it as an investment amongst that incumbent group.

JOHNSON: Why don't you like Apple?

HAWTIN: OK. So it is a tricky one because it's cheap. Apple is cheap.

JOHNSON: Yes.

HAWTIN: And if I was a pension fund manager, I'd probably be more seriously considering it as the kind of company to have in the portfolio. But as a growth technology company, it's far from growth to be honest. Expectations of growth over the next couple years is a low single digit top line. If the X is actually less successful than is expected, and that seems to be what's panning out here, then actually growth could be full even lower than that. So it's going to be a low to no growth company with a number I think of longer term risks.

JOHNSON: It feels in many ways a bit like kind of Microsoft a few years ago. It's kind of not generating a lot of top line growth but it's kind of kicking off a lot of cash and in many ways it depends on what kind of investor you are as to your attitude to whether or not you own it.

HAWTIN: It does and it does depend on what they do to change their business roadmap.

JOHNSON: Yes.

HAWTIN: And I think, you know, since the iPhone, there's not been an enormous amount of innovation. And even where there has been innovation, the opportunity for those innovative changes to create additional significant revenue are very limited against this massive sort of iceberg of iPhone unit sales. So I think that, you know, everyone is focusing on the service business now but that's coming under a lot of competitive pressure from companies like Amazon Prime Video, for example on the iTunes side.

JOHNSON: One thing that people talk about when they talk about big tech is the regulatory risk. And we were talking about this yesterday on the program. It feels like we're coming out of a kind of 15-year regulatory cram down for the telecom sector. Is there a discount that I need to apply coming back to phase (ph) to some of these stocks because of the potential regulatory position that we may be getting over the next few years? And is that why the market almost did what it did last year? It's beginning to kind of factor in external factors other than simply what they can do in terms of top and bottom line and kind of what the bigger trajectory is here? Like Mark Zuckerberg talks about this year, he's got to fix Facebook. From the investor point of view, that sounds quite serious.

HAWTIN: Yes. Well, he would say that obviously because he needs to make sure that he is saying the right things.

JOHNSON: Yes.

HAWTIN: As such a large company, it's important that he is seen to be politically correct. And, you know, they are hiring another 15,000 people this year to monitor content and they're going to spend a lot of money doing that.

But I think that -- I think a lot of it has been factored in already and I think you're dead right. One of the reason why these growth names perhaps didn't do better last year was because of this perceived regulatory risk. But I think it will be an evolutionary factor. I don't think we're going to have a crashing down of regulation, which is going to heavily constrict these companies because to do that, quite frankly, it needs to be done on a global scale. And I cannot see a global initiative to crack down on the regulation of these businesses and no one country is going to want to risk being too aggressive themselves because then they risk vulcanizing themselves.

JOHNSON: So the Europeans who don't really have a tech sector to worry about.

HAWTIN: No, but they do I think realize that the internet is a vital part of their economy. The digital economy is becoming, you know, in many ways is because the physical economy. If you decide as one geographic unit to clamp down from a regulatory perspective and you risk the internet growth in your area, you're vulcanizing yourself and it could have long reaching consequences.

JOHNSON: Just from a kind of asset allocation point of view, do I overweight Asia and underweight Europe? Just kind of in sort of big picture here because of the fact that Asia has better tech companies and Europe doesn't have many. You've kind of named a couple already, SAP and so forth. But there aren't many. Is that a reason to be underweight Europe in 2018 do you think?

HAWTIN: I don't think it's right to make a decision on geographic allocation purely on how tech will do. And if you were going to make that decision, then you just continue to stick with the U.S.

JOHNSON: Right.

HAWTIN: I think it's interesting that although there's a perception that Asia is full of amazing technology companies, in reality, there are very few global leaders in Asia. There are some big players from a regional perspective, like the internet companies in China, but there are more global technology winners in Europe than there are in Asia. You know, there's SAP, there's SML leading their parts of the market.

JOHNSON: Right.

HAWTIN: There are very few real global leaders in Asia.

JOHNSON: Great to see you this morning, Mark. Thank you very much indeed --

HAWTIN: Thanks.

JOHNSON: -- for coming to see us here at Bloomberg. Mark Hawtin, Investment Director joining us from GAM on the tech sec.

[*]

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5S5S-SKX1-JCBG-G3W0-00000-00Mark Lister: Tech companies brace for headwinds2018-04-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:08:49ZLexisNexisNEWSGeneralMark Lister: Tech companies brace for headwinds

The high-flying US technology sector has been one of the best sharemarket performers in recent years. It was the top performer in 2017 with a 37 per cent gain, and is number one again so far this year.

It"s the most dominant sector in the market, now representing 25 per cent of the S&P 500 index.

However, there are signs of increasing challenges on the horizon. While all those exciting disruptors still have very strong prospects, the outlook has become a little more complicated.

Earnings growth remains well and truly in favour of the tech sector, with profits forecast to grow an impressive 22 per cent this quarter, compared to the same period a year ago. That"s well ahead of the S&P 500 average, which is also impressive at 17 per cent.

Netflix shares hit a record high last week on the back of a great result, which exceeded expectations. I"ll be surprised if we don"t see some equally impressive headlines from the likes of Amazon, Visa, Google and friends.

On the other side of the ledger, rising interest rates and increasing government scrutiny have taken the shine off some of the big tech companies. On the back of an improving economy, better wage growth and expectations of rising inflation, US interest rates are going up. The two-year Treasury yield is at the highest since 2008, and the Fed Funds Rate will soon surpass our Official Cash Rate for the first time in 17 years.

That"s a headwind for companies in the tech sector, or at least their share prices.

While sales and customer numbers are growing strongly, many still post only modest profits. Much of their valuation hinges on the profits we expect them to earn in the future, sometimes years from now.

When interest rates are very low, the opportunity cost of waiting for those profits and dividends to arrive is low. Investors aren"t missing much, because they aren"t getting any return in cash or bonds anyway.

As interest rates rise, that all changes. The opportunity cost of waiting rises, as those other asset classes all of a sudden generate a half-decent income, for very little risk.

In short, because the earnings streams for many tech companies are long dated, investors may not be willing to pay as much for them as interest rates rise.

Then there"s the prospect of increasing regulation, which is also a risk to some in the sector. We hadn"t heard of most of these companies 10 years ago, but today they are intertwined in our lives and we"ve become dependent on them.

They"ve established dominant positions in their industries, and it has become so difficult for competitors. They"ve become monopolies in some ways.

Having strong market power is a sure-fire way to attract the attention of regulators, while questionable behaviour around privacy issues has also raised the ire of the authorities.

The tech sector is wide and varied, and these risks don"t apply across the board to every company. The growth prospects are as exciting as they"ve ever been, so despite a few headwinds, the tech sector will still tick a lot of boxes for many long-term investors. However, it might not be plain sailing from here on.

bull Mark Lister is Head of Private Wealth Research at Craigs Investment Partners. This column is general in nature and should not be regarded as specific investment advice.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:3YT4-HYK0-003M-X4FX-00000-00Markman Takes Aim At Conventional Advice - Manager Blasts Tendency To Overdiversify Fund Portfolios2000-01-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:08:49ZLexisNexisB; Pg. 1Markman Takes Aim At Conventional Advice - Manager Blasts Tendency To Overdiversify Fund PortfoliosBy Adam Shell, Investor's Business Daily

Investor's Business Daily Here's a tip from money manager Robert Markman: If you want to achieve better long-term returns investing in mutual funds, the typical advice of fund experts and financial planners. Why? Most experts will tell you to spread your dollars among multiple asset classes, Markman says. Indeed, they'll tout the benefits of foreign diversification. Or explain why you must own small-cap stocks. Or sell you on the long-term potential of value-style funds. There's just one problem. That strategy, Markman says, results in poor results. "The conventional wisdom in the fund world may be conventional, but it's not wisdom," wrote Markman in his new book, "Hazardous to your Wealth: Extraordinary Popular Delusions and the Madness of Mutual Fund Experts." "All the fancy charts, arcane terminology and pseudo-scientific research can't hide one uncomfortable fact: The 'smart money' - the experts - have been turning in crummy results for some time." So what's Markman's recipe for investment success? Build an all-American portfolio of large-cap U.S. stock funds with big tech stakes - and resist the temptation to trade. "It's probable that you're much better off keeping the equity portion of your portfolio right in your own backyard," Markman wrote, adding that short-term money should be invested in risk-free investments like cash and short-term bonds. While Markman calls his strategy simple, critics say it's irresponsible, inappropriate and even dangerous. "His approach is dead wrong because it's a bet on a single market and a single asset class," said Harold Evensky, a Coral Gables, Fla.

-based financial planner who is a staunch defender of portfolio diversification and asset allocation. "If Markman is right and someone follows that strategy, he might be rich. But if he's wrong, he might end up poor." Markman disagrees. Planners like Evensky, he says, are overly cautious. They mistakenly equate short-term volatility with risk. Planners focus too much on protecting capital rather than building wealth, Markman believes. Rather than zeroing in on investments with the best long-term return potential, such as U.S. blue chips, they spread the risk among a bunch of investments. That strategy increases the odds that at any given time some portion of your portfolio will do well. It also means some holdings will fare poorly. "Deviations from long-term strategies in reaction to shorter-term events are most likely to detract value from your portfolio," Markman wrote. "The rule is that the connection between volatility and risk decreases as the time increases." If the fund industry is guilty of anything, it is that they have "been schooled on nonpredictive communications," said Geoff Bobroff, a fund industry consultant. Concentrating one's bets on America's biggest, fastest-growing companies has worked wonders the past five years, as U.S. big caps outperformed other types of stocks by a wide margin. Markman expects that trend to continue. The U.S. Advantage Why? U.S. companies have decided advantages over their foreign counterparts in today's global, high-tech economy, he argues. Wall Street benefits from stringent regulations, which results in an honest playing field, Markman says. That reduces the chances of market meltdowns caused by Russian-style corruption or the crony capitalism practiced in Asia. America's entrepreneurial spirit, superior colleges and the ease of quickly allocating capital to new ideas also help U.S. companies. America's biggest corporations also enjoy competitive advantages over foreign rivals and smaller companies, he says. Their vast resources give them an edge in marketing and R&D. Markman isn't saying that value stocks, small caps and foreign stock markets won't outperform U.S. large caps from time to time. Just that investing in U.S. blue chips is a sound long-term strategy that will increase your odds of achieving your long-term financial goals. Markman is highly critical of "tactical asset allocation." That strategy requires planners to tweak a client's asset mix to increase potential return or decrease risk. A Matter Of Timing But there's a downside, Markman said. Reducing your holdings in, say, "overvalued" U.S. blue chips and adding to your stake in "undervalued" value stocks is basically market timing in disguise. If value doesn't rebound, "you'll have little chance of achieving decent returns," Markman wrote. The other problem is that "at some point, this portfolio will be subject to another decision" - when to cut back on value stocks. "If you're an investor with a 10- to 20-year time horizon, shifting assets based on how you think tech stocks may perform over the next six to 12 months is, frankly, schizophrenic," according to Markman. One problem with Markman's strategy, critics say, is that it requires investors to stay committed to large-cap growth stocks in down markets. Most investors say they have long- time horizons, but in reality their holding period is much shorter, says Sheldon Jacobs, editor of The No-Load Fund Investor. Thus, betting on one asset class may be a risky strategy for investors who may need to tap their accounts to pay for college or purchase a home. "Nothing is forever," Jacobs said. "He's assuming the trend of large-cap performance is permanent. At some point, small caps and other asset classes will do better."

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5PCS-64C1-JDPT-T1SF-00000-00MARK OKERSTROM, CEO, EXPEDIA, ON BLOOMBERG TELEVISION REGARDING HIS NEW TITLE AS CEO AT EXPEDIA2017-08-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:08:49ZLexisNexisMARK OKERSTROM, CEO, EXPEDIA, ON BLOOMBERG TELEVISION REGARDING HIS NEW TITLE AS CEO AT EXPEDIA

August 31, 2017

NEWS PROGRAM

MARK OKERSTROM, CEO, EXPEDIA,

BARTON: Joining us now from San Francisco with more is Bloomberg Technology anchor, Emily Chang. Emily?

CHANG: Mark, thank you so much. Joining us now the new CEO of Expedia, Mark Okerstrom from Expedia Headquarters in Redmond, Washington.

Mark, thank you for joining us and congratulations. I know it's been a dramatic last few days. So I'm curious from your perspective, how did Dara tell you that he was considering this job and what was your reaction?

OKERSTROM: Well, you know, these things that you talked about them for years, you -- something like a sports analogy, you prepare the team for the big game.And you get a call on Sunday night and suddenly the game is in two weeks from now, it's in fact, tomorrow.

So it kind of unfolded a little bit like that. I think we were all ready for this events reality when it did unfold. I don't think it unfolded exactly how everyone would plan, but I think we're all pretty excited around Expedia. We're very happy for Dara and, you know, I'm really happy for the people at Uber, I think he's going to do a fantastic job there.

CHANG: Now, when it comes to you and your job, Barry Diller said no one else was even considered. I know that you and Dara have been working together for many, many years.

But, you know, what is your vision? What are some things that you might do differently?

OKERSTROM: Well, you know, as I've said I've been very involved in the strategic direction of this company for a very long time. Dara and I really have been locked, stepped in, in really all of the major strategic decisions along with our Chairman Barry Diller.

So I really don't have a long list of things that I'm dying to change. We've got a number of priorities across the company, certainly, becoming more international as one of our key priorities.

So I'll be very focus on making sure we continue to expand globally. The big transition we're doing at HomeAway is a huge priority.

So I think you're going to see a lot more of the same for us and if I do my job well maybe we can go even a little bit faster.

CHANG: So let's talk about that. You now have some deep ties to Uber's new CEO, what are some new way that you could work together, like perhaps, free Uber rides for Expedia customers?

OKERSTROM: You know, we've talked a long time about possible ways that we could work with Uber, integrating our service in to the Expedia app, of the hotels.com app or the HomeAway app.

I'm hopeful then in the future now that we've got a direct connection, those talks might be a little bit easier.

CHANG: Dara is walking in to an incredibly challenging situation by all accounts, an ousted founder who still wants a role in the company, several lawsuits, very difficult board dynamics.

I mean, we've heard a lot about how he can deal with big personalities. Tell us a little bit more about, you know, what -- why you think he has what it takes to take on some of these personnel challenges?

OKERSTROM: Well, I think above all, you know, Dara has one of the highest levels of emotional intelligence that I've ever seen.

He knows people, he is humble, he listens. And I think above all, you know, Dara makes the people around him better.

People want to be around him, people want to think like he does. He's a great role model, he's a man of high integrity, he values diversity, he values gender balance.

He really stands for a lot of the great things that from what we read anyways maybe lacking in Uber.

So I have 100 percent confidence that Uber is going to be a much better company under Dara's leadership.

CHANG: Now, the information retracted, a report that you were going with Dara to Uber, they were wrong. But there is a point there that Dara has a lot of executive positions to fill.

Are you at all concern that a number of executives from Expedia are going to follow him there?

OKERSTROM: Well, listen, I think we feel very good about our executive team. We've got I think one of the most talented executive teams out there.

We've been together for a very long time and they're really excited about the prospects around Expedia, Inc. They're highly engaged, they're highly committed.

We've been working together on a strategy that were not yet done. So there's lots of work yet to do ahead of us and I think we've been pretty good about our team.

CHANG: So speaking about Expedia specifically, Google in particular is becoming a bigger potential threat. They're making bigger moves in the travel business.

Do you see more opportunities there to take them on from a U.S. antitrust perspective as they make these moves and given this political climate, the skepticism around big tech in general?

OKERSTROM: Well, I think we're going to continue to protect our interest have we -- as we always has. I mean, Google is has been and we expect continue it will be a really great partner for us.

Now, they obviously have a very powerful position in the industry both in the U.S. and around the world.

We encourage regulators to keep them in check so that we can continue to have a healthy economy.

Meanwhile, organically, we're very focus on making sure that we execute strategies to ensure that we're always the first place for people to come to shop and book their travel.

I think there are combination of all of that, it will mostly be fine and I hope we'll have a constructive and positive relationship with Google for many, many years to come.

CHANG: Meantime, Airbnb continues to grow, of course, you guys have HomeAway. But are you happy with your home rental business or do you think you still have a long way to go to catch up to Airbnb?

OKERSTROM: Yes, well, you know, we're never happy with anything to be honest. We want our business to be significantly larger. This is a massive industry, 100 billion dollars of vacation rental bookings every year.

That's probably an understatement of the opportunity ahead. I think Airbnb has done an exceptional job of creating huge amount of awareness around the category.

And we're very fortunate to be in the position where we've got a business that is on the phenomenal trajectory to step up, you know, alongside Airbnb.

Our experience has been in our industry that there's always room for two. We think that Airbnb is going to be a great success and we also think that HomeAway is going to be a great success within the Expedia family.

CHANG: What about when it comes to Priceline there, you know, making bigger moves with Booking.com especially in your home market, how would characterize competition from Priceline and its intensity?

OKERSTROM: Well, it's been intense for, let's see, the last, you know, 15 years really since the beginning of our competition and I expect that to continue.

In terms of changes, I think no major change, you know, Priceline, Booking.com really exceptional companies. And we have the outmost respect for them.

They're making good progress in the U.S. as far as we can tell. We're making good progress in Europe and Asia, and Latin America as far as we can tell versus them.

And again, I think there's room for both of them, both of us. And I think we'll both have great futures ahead of us.

CHANG: Dara was very outspoken about politics especially when it came to President Trump. Do you think he will take a similar approach when it comes to not just policy issues but also moral issues?

OKERSTROM: Well, I think that we have a very important role as senior executives of companies to speak out against those things that are, you know, against our company's interest and against the interest of our employees.

So I will take, you know, as active role is required to do these things on a go forward basis.

CHANG: Now, one last question. When it comes to global growth, Ctrip.com also making some big moves around the world, where do you see the biggest competition coming from them?

OKERSTROM: Well, I think certainly, you know, China and Asia is the competitive grounds for Ctrip. They're also an excellent competitor.

You know, I've just say that in an industry as large as travel which is at 1.4 trillion dollar industry where online penetration around the world is, you know, shy of 50 percent where the opportunities are so huge, you're going to have competitors that are -- that are fierce competitors and strong competitors everywhere you look.

We've got many of them. I expect that'll continue for a long period of time. But we're happy with our progress, we've got a good relationship with Ctrip. We expect all of that could continue in the future.

CHANG: All right. Mark Okerstrom, new CEO of Expedia. Mark, thanks for joining us on your first, second day on the job, I guess it is. Mark Barton --

OKERSTROM: Exactly.

CHANG: -- I'll send it back to you.

OKERSTROM: Thanks.

BARTON: Emily, great job. Thanks for joining us today, Bloomberg's Emily Chang there speaking to the new Chief Executive of Expedia. Fantastic interview here on Bloomberg Markets.

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

EMILY CHANG, BLOOMBERG NEWS

MARK BARTON, BLOOMBERG NEWS

Mark, thank you for joining us and congratulations. I know it's been a dramatic last few days. So I'm curious from your perspective, how did Dara tell you that he was considering this job and what was your reaction?

I'm hopeful then in the future now that we've got a direct connection, those talks might be a little bit easier.

I mean, we've heard a lot about how he can deal with big personalities. Tell us a little bit more about, you know, what -- why you think he has what it takes to take on some of these personnel challenges?

CHANG: All right. Mark Okerstrom, new CEO of Expedia. Mark, thanks for joining us on your first, second day on the job, I guess it is. Mark Barton --

OKERSTROM: Exactly.

CHANG: -- I'll send it back to you.

OKERSTROM: Thanks.

BARTON: Emily, great job. Thanks for joining us today, Bloomberg's Emily Chang there speaking to the new Chief Executive of Expedia. Fantastic interview here on Bloomberg Markets.

urn:contentItem:5PCM-BMD1-JB20-G4D3-00000-00Mark Okerstrom is interviewed on Bloomberg Television.2017-08-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:08:49ZLexisNexisBLOOMBERG TV12:00 AM ESTMark Okerstrom, Emily ChangNEWSInternational083181cb.550Mark Okerstrom is interviewed on Bloomberg Television.Mark Barton

Mark Okerstrom discusses his new title as CEO at Expedia.

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

MARK OKERSTROM, CEO, EXPEDIA, IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TV

AUGUST 31, 2017

SPEAKERS: MARK OKERSTROM, CEO, EXPEDIA

EMILY CHANG, BLOOMBERG NEWS

MARK BARTON, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] MARK BARTON, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Joining us now from San Francisco with more is Bloomberg Technology anchor, Emily Chang. Emily?

EMILY CHANG, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Mark, thank you so much. Joining us now the new CEO of Expedia, Mark Okerstrom from Expedia Headquarters in Redmond, Washington.

Mark, thank you for joining us and congratulations. I know it's been a dramatic last few days. So I'm curious from your perspective, how did Dara tell you that he was considering this job and what was your reaction?

MARK OKERSTROM, CEO, EXPEDIA: Well, you know, these things that you talked about them for years, you -- something like a sports analogy, you prepare the team for the big game.And you get a call on Sunday night and suddenly the game is in two weeks from now, it's in fact, tomorrow.

So it kind of unfolded a little bit like that. I think we were all ready for this events reality when it did unfold. I don't think it unfolded exactly how everyone would plan, but I think we're all pretty excited around Expedia. We're very happy for Dara and, you know, I'm really happy for the people at Uber, I think he's going to do a fantastic job there.

CHANG: Now, when it comes to you and your job, Barry Diller said no one else was even considered. I know that you and Dara have been working together for many, many years.

But, you know, what is your vision? What are some things that you might do differently?

OKERSTROM: Well, you know, as I've said I've been very involved in the strategic direction of this company for a very long time. Dara and I really have been locked, stepped in, in really all of the major strategic decisions along with our Chairman Barry Diller.

So I really don't have a long list of things that I'm dying to change. We've got a number of priorities across the company, certainly, becoming more international as one of our key priorities.

So I'll be very focus on making sure we continue to expand globally. The big transition we're doing at HomeAway is a huge priority.

So I think you're going to see a lot more of the same for us and if I do my job well maybe we can go even a little bit faster.

CHANG: So let's talk about that. You now have some deep ties to Uber's new CEO, what are some new way that you could work together, like perhaps, free Uber rides for Expedia customers?

OKERSTROM: You know, we've talked a long time about possible ways that we could work with Uber, integrating our service in to the Expedia app, of the hotels.com app or the HomeAway app.

I'm hopeful then in the future now that we've got a direct connection, those talks might be a little bit easier.

CHANG: Dara is walking in to an incredibly challenging situation by all accounts, an ousted founder who still wants a role in the company, several lawsuits, very difficult board dynamics.

I mean, we've heard a lot about how he can deal with big personalities. Tell us a little bit more about, you know, what -- why you think he has what it takes to take on some of these personnel challenges?

OKERSTROM: Well, I think above all, you know, Dara has one of the highest levels of emotional intelligence that I've ever seen.

He knows people, he is humble, he listens. And I think above all, you know, Dara makes the people around him better.

People want to be around him, people want to think like he does. He's a great role model, he's a man of high integrity, he values diversity, he values gender balance.

He really stands for a lot of the great things that from what we read anyways maybe lacking in Uber.

So I have 100 percent confidence that Uber is going to be a much better company under Dara's leadership.

CHANG: Now, the information retracted, a report that you were going with Dara to Uber, they were wrong. But there is a point there that Dara has a lot of executive positions to fill.

Are you at all concern that a number of executives from Expedia are going to follow him there?

OKERSTROM: Well, listen, I think we feel very good about our executive team. We've got I think one of the most talented executive teams out there.

We've been together for a very long time and they're really excited about the prospects around Expedia, Inc. They're highly engaged, they're highly committed.

We've been working together on a strategy that were not yet done. So there's lots of work yet to do ahead of us and I think we've been pretty good about our team.

CHANG: So speaking about Expedia specifically, Google in particular is becoming a bigger potential threat. They're making bigger moves in the travel business.

Do you see more opportunities there to take them on from a U.S. antitrust perspective as they make these moves and given this political climate, the skepticism around big tech in general?

OKERSTROM: Well, I think we're going to continue to protect our interest have we -- as we always has. I mean, Google is has been and we expect continue it will be a really great partner for us.

Now, they obviously have a very powerful position in the industry both in the U.S. and around the world.

We encourage regulators to keep them in check so that we can continue to have a healthy economy.

Meanwhile, organically, we're very focus on making sure that we execute strategies to ensure that we're always the first place for people to come to shop and book their travel.

I think there are combination of all of that, it will mostly be fine and I hope we'll have a constructive and positive relationship with Google for many, many years to come.

CHANG: Meantime, Airbnb continues to grow, of course, you guys have HomeAway. But are you happy with your home rental business or do you think you still have a long way to go to catch up to Airbnb?

OKERSTROM: Yes, well, you know, we're never happy with anything to be honest. We want our business to be significantly larger. This is a massive industry, 100 billion dollars of vacation rental bookings every year.

That's probably an understatement of the opportunity ahead. I think Airbnb has done an exceptional job of creating huge amount of awareness around the category.

And we're very fortunate to be in the position where we've got a business that is on the phenomenal trajectory to step up, you know, alongside Airbnb.

Our experience has been in our industry that there's always room for two. We think that Airbnb is going to be a great success and we also think that HomeAway is going to be a great success within the Expedia family.

CHANG: What about when it comes to Priceline there, you know, making bigger moves with Booking.com especially in your home market, how would characterize competition from Priceline and its intensity?

OKERSTROM: Well, it's been intense for, let's see, the last, you know, 15 years really since the beginning of our competition and I expect that to continue.

In terms of changes, I think no major change, you know, Priceline, Booking.com really exceptional companies. And we have the outmost respect for them.

They're making good progress in the U.S. as far as we can tell. We're making good progress in Europe and Asia, and Latin America as far as we can tell versus them.

And again, I think there's room for both of them, both of us. And I think we'll both have great futures ahead of us.

CHANG: Dara was very outspoken about politics especially when it came to President Trump. Do you think he will take a similar approach when it comes to not just policy issues but also moral issues?

OKERSTROM: Well, I think that we have a very important role as senior executives of companies to speak out against those things that are, you know, against our company's interest and against the interest of our employees.

So I will take, you know, as active role is required to do these things on a go forward basis.

CHANG: Now, one last question. When it comes to global growth, Ctrip.com also making some big moves around the world, where do you see the biggest competition coming from them?

OKERSTROM: Well, I think certainly, you know, China and Asia is the competitive grounds for Ctrip. They're also an excellent competitor.

You know, I've just say that in an industry as large as travel which is at 1.4 trillion dollar industry where online penetration around the world is, you know, shy of 50 percent where the opportunities are so huge, you're going to have competitors that are -- that are fierce competitors and strong competitors everywhere you look.

We've got many of them. I expect that'll continue for a long period of time. But we're happy with our progress, we've got a good relationship with Ctrip. We expect all of that could continue in the future.

CHANG: All right. Mark Okerstrom, new CEO of Expedia. Mark, thanks for joining us on your first, second day on the job, I guess it is. Mark Barton --

OKERSTROM: Exactly.

CHANG: -- I'll send it back to you.

OKERSTROM: Thanks.

BARTON: Emily, great job. Thanks for joining us today, Bloomberg's Emily Chang there speaking to the new Chief Executive of Expedia. Fantastic interview here on Bloomberg Markets.

[*]

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***
